http://www.audible.com/pd/Sci-Fi-Fantasy/The-Weight-of-Blood-Audiobook/B01IE144AI/

Well, it's finally ready. The first book of the Half-Orcs, The Weight of Blood, is now out in audiobook format on audible! Now, it's actually been out for a bit, but I've been delaying because I've been waiting for a gift from Audible: 25 free copies of the book for me to give away to all of you!

So, finally want the audio version? Haven't read it because you're an audio only type of person? Now's your chance to get it free. All you need to do is post below telling me where you'll expect to listen to it, be it on walks, car rides, on a plane, or during a trip to the moon. On the 12th I'll randomize the lucky 25 and notify them through messages on how to redeem their copies.

Thanks, good luck, and enjoy!

data.message: I'll be sending out messages to all the winners shortly, so make sure to keep an eye on your inbox.

data.message: Unreal, David. Un-freaking-real. People have been telling me to fix my posture for years, but your blog post might have just done that. Hope you start getting better soon!

David, I must admit to being a bit frustrated with the lack of news on your book but the way you have described that journey of yours over the past few months makes me feel like a real bastard for even thinking anything bad. I forget, and I'm sure we all do, that sometimes real life takes priority 😊 all the best for a full and swift recovery mate!

It's nice that you've taken some time to explain things to your fans. It's not necessary, but it shows you care and that you're a genuinely great person. I hope you feel better after the next round of 'hunt the nerve'!
I just started reading Skyborn yesterday and finished it today!. Definitely gonna get Fireborn. But, I saw that there was a 3rd book called Shadowborn. When will that be coming out?

Wow. I can relate on so many levels. With the severity of your neck issues it probably won't help, but have you tried a TENS device? I'd never heard of them until my mom was suffering from the same type of nerve pain you described (only in her back) and was using them to try to alleviate it. This is a great one: http://www.amazon.com/AccuRelief-Channel-Electrotherapy-Relief-System/dp/B00KPLDX3U/ref=sr_1_13_a_it?ie=UTF8&qid=1458241115&sr=8-13&keywords=tens+unit   They're not horribly expensive either, which is a plus. I have fits with my neck, too, because my posture sucks and because I'm a stomach sleeper, and using this helps when I wake up and can't move my head.
Just read the first book in the series and loved it.  I hope you're feeling better and I'm excited for the Fireborn release in November!

sorry for your pain DAvid. I  hope you are better. I love your books though read all of them except broken worlds series and finishing up the half-orc series and i got to admit this half orc series and then paladin series has gotten me addicted. I love haerns personality and tarlaks personality, the romance between both of the half orcs and the lovers, and the fact you got all the characters into one series that was what really made me excited to be reading these books. Keep up the good work man!

Hey, David! I'm sad to hear that you're having to go through all this. However, I'm happy to hear that you're recovering. I've been around family with similar problems, so I understand in a small way how horrendous they can be. I wish you only the best! I hope the road to recovery is smooth, the ride Swift, and may your axles remain forever greased ;)

Feel better.  Tough road you're wandering down. Stay positive and know only good things are coming.

One of my all time favorite writers easily.

You are so talented you even make a sick note entertaining! Sounds awful and I hope things continue to improve for you health wise! Stress and depression are the hardest things to recognise but relatively easy to manage once you have. I read your books when things start to get on top of me and they wisk me away to another world for a while!!

I'm glad things are going better for you. I hope things continue to improve. Your writing has been a blessing to me. Ironically, it helps me fight through my own procrastination. There are several things I have always had a horribly hard time making myself do. I put on one of your Audiobooks and fight through til' they are done. Thanks man.

All I can say is wow!!! And like so many others, I feel like a complete jerk for even being the slightest bit annoyed about the longer wait!! But on a higher note, super glad you are getting yourself taken care of! We all know that when life comes to bite, it usually bites hard! Hate you had to go through all that. I can only imagine! But great to know you are getting better! Hang in there David!
From a long time fan to a author i greatly respect...you are not alone in your journey. ..be well and endure.

Wow, so sorry to hear you've been through all that in the last few months. It's wonderful how your publisher was so understanding.  Very glad the book is done and can't wait to read it! Hope you're feeling better soon!
Boo hoo. Get you ass in gear and finish the damned book. See that? That's tough love. In all honesty, take your time, regroup, then finish the damned book.
Hope all will be well soon. Have not gotten to read this series yet but look forward to doing so this summer!!!

You got this David!!! Stay Strong, and get through the anxiety and depression. You've got thousand of fans that support you and will help when and where we can. Thanks for the up date and we are glad that you are getting better. Stay strong!!! :D You got this!
You are awesome. Hang in there! I've to deal with neck/back pain as well. Exercise and stretching is usually what helps the most for me. Get well and feel better!
Damn David Dalglish I'm sorry you've had such a rough time man. I hope you get better and keep fighting through the tough times. One day at a tme bro. One day at a time. .

You know. I have a tbi, which provides me with all those symptoms you described plus a few more. Tried many medicines to no avail. So I completely understand your position. Goid on you for getting help for the depression and know many people love your creative mind and simply couldn't do without your stories. I know I do do want to read more and so does my wife.

Thank you for being very open and honest with your condition and your personal health. Very pleased that you're on the road to recovery, but take your time....... we're not going anywhere and will patiently wait. Your recovery is more important xx
Hope all your troubles go away; if only for the very selfish reason of getting to read more of your books :) But seriously take the time for YOU that you need, you'll be in my thoughts.
Take care of yourself, David. We all love and support you. We can wait for the next project while you do what you need to to be better.
Heal and stay well. Please consider continuing with yoga as it is very helpful in many ways - physically, emotionally and mentally.
I hope you feel better soon, David :) Don't worry if you have to put off writing for a while, we understand.

*reads blog* *reads reasons* *reads medical adventures* Yep, you're a writer. Sympathies-dealing with neck pains myself. They're crap. Patient fans will stay patient. Other fans will return if you're a good writer. The rest...well, never mind. Do what you have to.
Anti-depressant is like an shotgun to the mind, go get talk therapy!
Jeez, hope you're feeling better.
No pressure! Rushing would just make the work suffer.
Hope you get your health sorted soon. For your own sake, not mine and your other readers.
Wish you a complete recovery and may it be as soon as possible.
So sorry for your struggles but also very proud of you.  Hang in there!   Hugs!
Get better soon...reading is my anti-depressant. ...so my medicine is you
Get better fist, the rest will follow ... we'll wait ...
Nothing like a dose of the blues. Don't sweat it. We'll still be here waiting for 1/2 Orchs
Just do your best man, we will be patient for you
Get well soon David
:( feel better soon!
Stay strong!

message:
Mr. Dalglish,
I have been reading your books for about a year now and started with the 6 shadowdance books and now have moved onto Half-Orcs. My question is what is the official continuity regarding Haern and Thren? In the Shadowdance books it was apparent that Tarlack and company knew Thren was Haren's father but in The half orcs when they assaulted the Spider guild they acted surprised that Thren was the guildmaster and easily overwhelmed them. Which one is the real narrative and would you ever want to revisit this in a future revision?

data.message: Fireborn.
Sounds great to me. There was no wrong answer to this question.

message:
Just finished the last book in The Shadowdance Series, and... wow.
Seriously, Bravo David Dalglish. 
Not only for an amazing series that kept me hooked from start to finish, but that last book alone was so incredible.
The very last twist in particular on the last pages of the epilogue, I just did not see coming at all, and I'm so excited for whatever happens next with it all. I seriously have the chills right now from everything I just read. The end left me feeling very satisfied I must say, and yet... I want more! So so much more.

I know you said in the afterword that you have plans for that particular twist I just mentioned, and oh gods, I just cannot wait.

It is writers like yourself that inspire me to keep trying, so I just want to say thank you so much for all your hard work.
I look forward to what comes next~

message: so, i just wanted to tell you how inspiring your books are. i found "The paladins Omnibus" on the google store. i sampled it and read the first, night of wolves, fell in love with your writing. so i checked out your other works. i had heard of shadow dance before, and never read it. but i spotted the half orc series. i was intrigued. i read the first book and instantly i was immersed in the world of dezrel. i HATED the Tun brothers at first. wondered how they could salughter innocents, how they could be so heartless, and i thought to my self, why am i even reading this? this is dark. its not fun to read. but then i got through the whole book, and red your prologue. "its a story of redemption". right. how could harruq and qurrah possibly redeem themselves. so i read on and on and on. i can now say that your land of dezrel and its denizens are my favorite series of all time. thank you david dalglish, for writing the mystical tales of dezrel.

data.message:
Nope, you got it right. Combination of two things.

One: Faceless are pretty much an eastern thing, Gray Sisters the west
.
Two: The Gray Sisters are more like internal police, assassins trained to keep an eye on their own kind, whereas the Faceless are more a unique punishment that has been warped to be of more use to Karak's order. Make sense?

I just found it odd that the followers of Karak would have seperate female groups within their faith. data.message:
Spoilers, obviously:

Actually having Qurrah die at the bridge was because I knew I needed something big from him. Here was the guy I'd spent four books building up to be a villain. If I was going to get readers to believe it, I needed a legitimate sacrifice on his part. The stand at the bridge came about pretty naturally. Fight against former teacher? Check. Potential chance to reunite with Tess, and possibly save her from Velixar as well? Check. Selfless sacrifice that makes Qurrah look epic? Check.

message: King of the Vile finished, now make moar! The authors notes at the end were interesting. SPOILERS I remember one of your old authors notes you mentioned that Harruq was going to kill Qurrah but you felt like it wasnt right for the character, I assumed that having Qurrah die later in that last stand against Velixar was meant to get the story back on the line you had originally intended and everything was to be the same as originally planned from there.

It's been two years, but your wait is finally over. Can't describe how excited I am, and how eager I am for you to finally read the next installment. What happens to Tarlak inside the Council of Mages? How will Jessilynn fare against the besieging army of beast-men? Who is the shadowy figure manipulating the angels? All here. All awesome.

Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00STSL6JY
B&N: http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/the-king-of-the-vile-david-dalglish/1121129261
iTunes: should be ready to purchase.

Nook is processing, should be up within the day. Print versions should be ready in a day or two as well.

So there you have it. To everyone who has asked me when the next Half-Orc book is, I can finally answer: right now :-)

A Dance of Death is what the book was called when I first self-published it. Changed the name for the re-release of it (which if I'd known how much confusion it'd cause, I never, ever would have done).

I discuss a tiny bit more about that here: http://ddalglish.com/wp/2013/12/03/a-dance-of-mirrors-so-whats-new/

message:
Hi David! 

My apologies if this is a stupid question that you've possibly been asked a thousand times....

I've recently started reading the Shadowdance series (I know, I'm slow off the starting block with this one) and just purchased book 3 "A Dance of Mirrors" but I have some people telling me that book 3 is actually "A Dance of Death". 

Is it the same book, renamed from when you were self-publishing? Or is A Dance of Death separate? 

Thanks!

data.message:
There's remote possibilities for new paladins books (Fall of the Citadel, perhaps, or a single fifth book continuing the last four) but they're on back-burner status.

As for villain back stories: I've actually done this several times. Cloak and Spider is all about Thren Felhorn. The Breaking World Trilogy is partly a gigantic story of both Velixar and Karak and how they became who they are. Even the Half-Orcs sorta does this in following Qurrah for the earlier half of the series.

I do hope to crank out a Tarlak short story collection, which would at least give some fun early stories involving the Eschaton.

message: will you ever work on any new paladins books and stories about your villans personal lives and how they became evil would be nice as well as the heroes themselves--like the early years of the orc brothers and adventures of the escheton.

data.message: I love the ending to Broken Pieces a lot, which makes me hesitant to do anything that might tweak it in any way (even Darius's cameo in Prison of Angels had me a little worried). There is a slight, and I mean slight, possibility I write a fifth Paladin novel to clarify what happened to her and Kaide and the like.

message: So I just finished re-reading Paladins for the third time or so and I have to ask, whatever happens to Valessa? Any future plans for her?

data.message: Nothing quite so dramatic, but when someone like Velixar is talking, he's usually expressing the worst parts of me, or my thoughts, or my fears, or just how I feel when I'm tired and cranky on a Monday morning.

message: do you ever feel that when you write about the evil in your villans that some of that evil can manifest in yourself or make you look deeper into yourself?

For those keeping an eye out for King of the Vile, the rough draft's done, and currently in the editing stages. Expect it late this month. Would have had it sooner, but the book ended up about 20% longer than I originally expected. I doubt you'll all mind, though :-)

Almost three weeks out now, so I hope all of you are enjoying A Dance of Ghosts. A few of you have written reviews on Amazon and B&N, and I'm incredibly thankful for them. If you've finished the book, please consider tossing up a review at Amazon (or B&N, or iTunes, or Google Play, or wherever it is you grabbed it). Those reviews help fuel a lot of reader recommendations, automated emails, and just swaying people on the fence. I very, very much need them, and appreciate them.

This shameless begging is now concluded. You may go about your daily Facebook day :-)

message: I finished The Dance of Ghosts. It's a helluva a story that tackles some pretty heavy themes. I love all your books, but I haven't felt as emotionally affected by one since The Broken Pieces.

A DANCE OF GHOSTS, now on sale!
No, this isn't a republish. This isn't re-edited. This is new, brand new, the never before released continuing adventures of Haern the Watcher as he joins his father, Thren Felhorn, in an attempt to infiltrate the Stronghold, bastion of the dark paladins of Karak. Are you excited yet? If not, why are you not excited yet?!?

message:
Dawn of Swords: Epic fantasy. Free for everyone. Seriously. For real.

Do you have a Kindle? Or a device that can use the Kindle App? If so, for the next three days, you can download, for free, with no strings attached, the entire first book of the Breaking World Trilogy. If you want more details, just swing by my website for the post here, as well as the necessary links.

http://ddalglish.com/wp/2014/10/20/free-dawn-of-sword-until-oct-23/

So, if you haven't already grabbed the series, maybe delayed for some reason, now you have no excuse :-)

data.message: David, this is why I love you. You really care about your fans, and offer us great incentive to read your works. Or, ya know, have a really smart marketing team to get us hooked! Either way, write on, brother!

message:
Note to self: never promise to try to tally up something with 50 different potential entrants, not counting foreign nations...

Okay! First off, I've sent friend invites and messages to the winners of the giveaways, so congratz Jordan Funk, Donny Breder, and Cindy Goosen (I decided to give an extra away).

Winning state was Florida (lots of reading on the beach I'm guessing), so I also chose at random someone from there, so congratz Donna Weinbrecht. Also, not much of a surprise, but UK came in as the solid lead for non-US, beating out Canada by a 2-1 margin.

Anyhoo, that was fun, thanks for all the comments (and attempts at jokes those who made the effort), and look forward to the next giveaway! :-)
Florida !!!

Do you want one of these? Of course you do. So two lucky people are going to get this book a good *month* before it's official release. I'm giving away two, one in the US, one outside. So to enter, simply follow these directions:

If you're inside the US, shout out your state (I'll tally up which state wins btw, out of pure pointless curiosity).

If you're outside the US, post your country. (I'll also tally up, but I have a feeling the UKs got this one in the bag).

I'll notify the winners tomorrow morning (Oct 11). So, feeling lucky? Want to read the continuing adventures of Haern and Thren as they go on a jolly father/son trip? Then start typing :-)

data.message: Of all the death scenes I've done, that one is easily my favorite, without question.

I just finished reading the paladins and logged on to see what people had to say about Darius' death. Epic and glorious as it was, I believe the despair was felt by everyone, and it needed to be felt. Perfect.

message: When Darius died at the end of the paladin series it was truly an epic glorious death but i was in despair at his death! he had gone through trial after trial and found redemption i wanted him to be free from strife (i know selfish) and be happy to fall in love with Valessa! none the less it was an epic read, am waiting on blood of the gods so much !

So A Dance of Shadows has been out for nearly two weeks, yet it has a whopping 1 review on Amazon, none on B&N, and 3 on Amazon UK..with two of them just informing people of the name change.

That's..that's kind of disappointing, guys and gals. I hate to be shameless and beg, but these reviews are really important. They help convince new readers if the series is worth their time, as well as affect how the automated aspects of the mailers and recommendations of these various sites operates. So, um, pretty, pretty please, if you've enjoyed these Haern books, care to help me out? :-)

My stance on fanfic is pretty simple: so long as you aren't selling it, you can write whatever the heck you want, post it wherever the heck you want, draw whatever the heck you want, etc. Heck, I don't care if you make tips on it or whatever on some clever setup, just so long as there's nothing on Amazon/B&N etc that might cause actual confusion.

message:
Dear Mr. Dalglish:

 Are you opposed to people writing fanfiction stories in your universe? Or are you one of those few authors that would seek out such trespassers of your delightful sandbox as it were, and sick your lawyers on them like thirsting starved hell hounds? I can only imagine what that would be like...

You: “Hmm this handicapped fellow is writing a story based on my works on his laptop completely for self entertainment and isn't putting it out online. God I love being a hacker and an author. Bruiser, Blades, bring this guy to me. He thinks he's crippled now, wait till we finish destroying his worthless life!” *evil maniacal laughter* 

Me: “Well I live off $200 a month, you can have that and my cellphone. But it's all I got.”

You: *evil eye squint* “Take his kidneys. We can sell em for thirty grand on the black market that should just about cover it. Have a wonderful rest of your life, so glad you enjoyed my books.”

Clearly I hope that you'd be anything but that and from what I've read it seems like you're a all around great guy. That being said would you sick the hounds on me if I chose to write my own little fanfiction of your work? It'd show a copyright to you and state it was for non profit if I even decided to post it online to begin with. Hope all is well and I truly enjoy your work.

Respectfully,

Pat

message:
Well, today's the day: another big release, this time the (massively) rewritten Blood of the Underworld, now officially part of the Shadowdance series like it should have always been:

http://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/david-dalglish/a-dance-of-shadows/9780316242424/

I'll have the primer up in a few hours most likely, detailing as many of the changes as I can remember. In short, though, this is probably the first of the re-launched titles I would highly recommend grabbing even if you read the original, due to how many tweaks I made, and how they will affect the final two books in the series.

So new readers or old, hope you enjoy :-)

data.message: Also, all those old reviews by all of you good people for Blood of the Underworld are now gone. If any of you grab the new one, or heck, just read it for the first time, I'd much appreciate any and all reviews on any and all websites and whatnot :-)

I'm often asked why Tarlak wears yellow. Now while I do have an in-lore reason for it, it's not the actual real reason I had Tarlak start out as a mage in yellow. That reason, I've decided to finally reveal today. Attached is an image from an old game, Ultima Online. The very first incarnation of Tarlak came from there, played by my brother. Using the dye tubs, he always made sure his character had this color scheme...

And now you know. Everything unique about me, I've generally stolen from my friends and family ;-)

message:
Alrighty, random picks are in. Joe Lukowski and Meg Winking, check your FB messages :-)

Thanks to everyone else who entered! Hopefully I'll get to do another one of these soon.

Another giveaway! This time for the audiobook version of Dawn of Swords! I have both the 17 audio cd set, and the single MP3 cd, so whoever wins gets to choose which format they'd like to receive. So, to enter all I need to know is this:

Where do you plan on listening to the audiobook version?

I'll announce the winner Wednesday. Aaaand go.

*edited to add* Going to go ahead and pick two winners, because already getting more entries than I expected for the audiobook version.

message:
Lot of votes, lot of close calls, but in the end, I guess I shouldn't be surprised who managed to sneak out a victory at the end.

Also, I've contacted the winner of the signed giveaway (a Velixar voter, so perhaps some dark magic was involved). If you didn't win, well, you're in luck! Rob'll be holding a second giveaway this Monday for a signed copy, as well as another nifty little bonus...appearing in one of the Breaking World books as a fleshed out character.

Thanks to everyone who voted! I'm going to get started out cranking out a little short story for Haern, and will post it up on my website for free when it's finished!

message:
Hi David!  I was wondering if you ever promote at conventions?  It would be cool to see you at a con sometime and get a book signed.  I'm a big fan.  :D  

By the way, just finished Dawn of Swords and it was awesome.  Looking forward to the next installment.  Thanks for all the great books!

*edit* Contest closed, see most recent post! */edit*

Well, in honor of Dawn of Swords fantastic launch, me and Rob are giving away a signed copy (by the both of us) to a random winner right here. This is a reward for the fans, so to do this, you'll have to really, really, really prove your fandom. So, make sure to follow these very specific instructions if you'd like to enter for a chance at this sexy huge book.

In the comments below, post the answer to the following question...

What....is your favorite character from any of my books?

I'll announce the winner Saturday morning. Aaaand go.

data.message: You know what...screw it. Let's have some fun. Highest tally character gets a new short story I'll release for free on my website.
Wow guys. I'm honestly really flattered by the sheer variety of characters.
Side note: I'll probably tally these up just to see who ends up with the most votes. Gut says Haern, but hey, maybe Darius or Harruq pull off an upset ;-)
Death mask
I can't decide... Ahh! Probably Tess. Ya, she was awesome.
Tess, her passion, desire and mind. Sheer beauty in brutality.
Qurrah because his inner turmoil was very well done
Haern!

a simple question. a tough question to answer.  i bounced back and forth between several characters including jerico, qurrah, and harruq. In the end I decided Ill have to re-read all of your books to decide in truth, but for now I'll say Haern. The hidden hero. The passionate yet subdued.
So many characters to choose from.  Haern always kept me excited to see what he would do next.
So many nice characters but the best ones are Darius and Haern. They really drive the reader to want to read, more, more, and more!
Jerico!
Haern and Darius
Haern.
Jerico for me, I love his faith and strength. I really enjoyed the ending to the paladins series,  I felt like it was a great conclusion for part of his story and I cant wait to read more about him.
Qurrah-for bad-assery
It's all about Haern, not the Watcher the old man

The man with the shield. Jericho was always the best I'm every chapter he was in. He was a tank, but he wasn't just the shield. He was the moral for the group on many occasions. Wouldn't of been the same without him.

Darius, for me his internal conflict hit home. Belief  be it political, religious or even jingoistic beliefs in one's country. Regardless of how justified one feels objectively none of those topics are 0 or 1.  (edited ) Darius embodied the conflict that can occur because of this. While most of your characters have developed depth over the books , He is up there with Erikson's best characters in my humble opinion. (there you go )
Has to be Tessanna for me, so strong but yet frail too. :- D
Haern he's my favorite character ever
I actually really like Ezekai in last half-orc book, especially at the end. Even though he had limited "screen time" so to speak, there is A LOT of potential for him and his story.
Haern and then Jerico
The Half-Orc Series drew me in and I have been a fan ever since!! Qurrah Tun is my vote.
Not entering the contest, but Qurrah.  Because of reasons. :)
I'm definitely thinking it has to be Darius. Giant badass sword+ the turmoil= great story (Although almost all of the characters have a great story)
Haern
Thren Felhorn!! Lovable anti hero!
Harruq!
Haern, since I started with a dance of cloaks (or Aaron technically... but Aaron was what he didn't want to be..)
Dieredon!!! Why because he is a total bad ass warrior!!!
Velixar!!! He is the perfect villain!!! You hate him so much but really admire his power skill and devotion to his God!!!
"The humans are weak. Their skin is soft. And their minds are dull from years of safety. We are the vicious. We are the destroyers!"  REDCLAW   Nuff said  :-)
Hurruq...nice to finally see a likeable Orc, even if he is only half.
Zusa. She is amazing and get shit done.
Darius is great.  Wish there were more books about him.
Brug! :)

Qurrah. Really hard to answer but I gotta go with him because he's the one whose name I try to grab first in any mmo I try. Love the name, love his abilities, and most of all I love his "human-ess". He isn't good or evil, he's gray. Like every human alive.
Redclaw... I've always liked getting the bad guys point of view. Especially when they just want the best for their people.  Even if it's tasty human flesh.
Darius and Jerico. Their story was what got me hooked on your books. Got the first book free on the kindle and I cant stop reading everything you wrote.

I love harruq and qurrah. Think you captured their struggles in life and overcame it all, earned their acceptance really well. Qurrah was my favorite of all of the twins. I have my 13 yr old son starting the half orc series now
Definitely gotta be Tess. She's crazy but so loveable. I adore her. Hearn is a very close second though
Its got to be hearn for his style and harruq for his way with words!
Harruq
Veliana. Bad ass woman with one eye. Stuff of pirate tales right?
I would have to say Harruq because he killed a god need I say more...
Dedredon the Elven Scoutmaster
Tarlak for me. Would love to see an origin story for him.
Darius was the best for sure but Jerico was also a great character and a great series!
Ruqsy, natch ;)
Robert Haern,through his teaching of the love of Ashhur.Helped make Aaron who he became.His death was tragic but it was needed in the end.

Jericho for sure, but I feel like I can sympathize with Haern... Then again, Veliana was very interesting, and I loved her personality. Deathmask's wit is something I wish I could have, but I'm sure Luther could contend easily. I see bits and pieces of myself in sooo many characters that it's hard to pick one for certain :P I've read every book but this one, I have to finish George RR martin's Song of Ice and Fire book 5 first ;)

Honestly, my gut instinct was for Darius, however after some thought I have to go with Velixar. Anyone can build a hero that people fall in love with, but it takes a special kind of villain that makes you really hate them and he was it. I applaud you for making me want to throw the books every time he came back!
Deathmask
Luther ye know just because! XD
Qurrah easily!
The watcher  ... Always had a weak spot for super rogues :/

Jerico the paladin for the example he sets toward his fellow man and the idea of protecting all thay need protecting, I also love the fact that he has a shield that is enchanted with power of his god instead of a weapon! (:
Yeah, I'll toss in my vote for Jericho due to his sheer ability stay strong in the face of adversary where others fell to darkness :D
Wraith!
Haern is my favourite
Darius for sure! His transition from Karak to Ashur was interesting, especially when he must team up with characters with similar paths albeit not on purpose
Aurelia strictly for putting up with Harruk, and because she's a girl.  :)
Jerico
Jericho for me. Strength and humility
Tessana.... she is just such a messed up tragic  character. I feel for her because she just can't help it.
Darius followed closely by Haern.
Haern although I love all the characters he was my favorite.
Brug. He is so bad at fighrin but still has a crack.
EASY!!!  Haern!!!  All day.  Every day.  Haern is the best character you have ever created, OR KILLED!!!  I wanted to cry when he died.  He was just so mysterious and larger than life.  I loved him.
Harruq. Man does anything for his family even at the start in a twisted way and I respect that.

Harruq is my favorite. The personal torment he went through to overcome the fact that he was a product of his hopeless environment  and the awful recurring circumstances of his life really struck a chord with me. He just seems so larger than life yet genuine all at the same time.
Qurrah Tun all the way
Deathmask is badass, he's the coolest and will do anything to protect his interests.

Either Tarlak for being quite funny and a wizard or Haern for sheer badassery

I also faintly remember the thieves from the ghost of the mountain book being pretty good characters that worked off each other very well.

EDIT: i'm reading through these and realizing, i like pretty much all of the characters are really good and it's to hard for me to actually choose one....

Has to be Harruq. He tries so hard to become a good person. He doesn't want to be anything else other than normal and happy. He pulls a sexy elf and he kills a god and pretty much be comes a king. What more can a guy as for.
Thren
Harruq! Dude is a beast and got the hot elf in his bed!
Jerico.  It's very refreshing knowing that a paladin can have some wit and charm instead of the usual "lawful stupid" nature that many people have come to despise.
Zusa
Definitely Darius, starts off being kinda dark but ends up being truly noble and dare I say 'human' :)
Jerico is my favorite character and I really hope to hear more about Darius.

Jerico humble, meek, never puts himself first, and can bash your  f skull if he has to. lol  The depth of characters is what makes a book i think, and David all your characters are more than just a name you make great ones and Most don't fall in good or evil, black or white but in a grey area that is more true to life. I do like Jerico but almost every character you create makes me want to know more about them. thank you for your work, hello and good luck to fellow fans, and congrats to the winner
Jerico for me
Harruq and his path to redemption, the first book got me hooked and I have read every one since. Love all your books!
My favourite character is Zusa, i love to see strong female characters mingling with the generic male heroes that we are all used to reading about.
My favorite characters are Haern and Zusa. Love your books! Have read them a bunch of times!
Haern, Harruq, Jerico, these are all great characters.
Haern Felhorn...reminded me of my childhood and how you can break from the molds that you're cast in to become something better.
Deathmask for me i love a jackass villian hero who will do what is needed to take what he has and then protect his claim.
Jericho was my favorite  I appreciate reading about characters who live by their principles.
Darius
Has to be Haern easily the coolest character. Harruq is great too though
Harruq,  he da man... orc... bit of both. Tough but fair.
Jericho. Flawed human who knows it and sees to rise above his baser instincts to help and do good.

Harruq is my favourite character in all of your book series I’ve read to date. He shows what it is to struggle between good and evil, to love family or to betray family. He teaches you that even when you’re down when all is lost that you can be strong you can save the ones you love. Harruq progression as a character through out your series is amazing and touching, you see parts of him die and then parts reborn into something new something completely different. He is a fictional character that people can relate to in real life, a character you can feel for – be a part of through out is life. He shows us the biggest thing in life is that everything is worth fighting for and that no matter the odds there is always hope in the darkest of moment when all else fails. Harruq forever the part of us we strive to be. 

P.s sorry it's so long.

Karak and Ashhur still walk the land, and you'll find bits and cameos from dozens of characters, families, and locations from throughout the Half-Orcs, Shadowdance, and Paladins. I really think this book is something special, and that you all will enjoy. So...enjoy Dawn of Swords!

message:
I promised it, so here it is, a list of the various changes to A Dance of Mirrors. I'd strongly recommend reading this, as I made some changes to the end of Mirrors that actually do have some ramifications to the remaining books of the series.

You can read the post here: http://ddalglish.com/wp/2013/12/03/a-dance-of-mirrors-so-whats-new/

All right, I keep getting begged and begged for *new* stuff, so here it is: Cloak and Spider, a novella dedicated to our favorite lovable bastard, Thren Felhorn. It's out, right now, for realz, buy it today, read it today, love it and review it and all that awesome stuff.

Also, don't forget A Dance of Mirrors launches today as well, so for all of you waiting to grab it, perhaps in print, it's up as well. I'll try to get the primer detailing the various changes up and posted sometime later today.

Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/Cloak-Spider-Shadowdance-David-Dalglish-ebook/dp/B00DQAFC0Y/

B&N: http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/cloak-and-spider-david-dalglish/1115888566

Should also be available on the iBookstore if you do a quick search!

You all have been clamoring for something new...so here's the biggie. This is the Breaking World, the telling of the Gods' War between Karak and Ashhur at the beginning of the world, the founding of the various Paladin factions, the early rumbling of the Trifect, Velixar's humble origins...they're all here in a brand new trilogy, starting with Dawn of Swords.

Pre-order is available on Amazon here, for release on January 14th: http://www.amazon.com/Dawn-Swords-Breaking-World-ebook/dp/B00CL0FAR0/

data.message: And yes, that *is* Karak on the right, Ashhur on the left.
For those echoing my own sentiments about the wait until this publishes, take solace in this: all three books in the Breaking World trilogy will hit in 2014.

Now all we need is the fall of the citidel, lathar's fight with darrakken, the blood of the father (and whatever book 3 is called), the continuation of the half Orc series, and Tarlak's origins. Some details about the tower of mages would be nice and I wouldn't complain if we got more on dierdon. So, nothing too difficult. All I can say is that at least until this is done you've got your number #1 fan here through the end.
Looking forward to it! Now what about those Tun brothers?

Throughout all the Half Orcs, Paladins, and Shadowdance books, I always thought "Wow, I wonder what Dezrel was like when Ashhur and Karak walked among the people and how the Gods war started." data.message:
I did a completely overhaul along with the help of the editors at Orbit. The ending got significantly tweaked, and I think an extra chapter. Nothing earth shattering, but I do think it helps the book.

Dance of Shadows was formerly known as Blood of the Underworld, in case you've already bought/read that one.

In terms of publishing, DoS should hit early 2014, DoG late 2014, adn I think DoCh really early 2015. So yeah, I'd just read Old Ways and then Broken Pieces. Those two also take place pretty separately from the Shadowdance series (at least until book 5).

data.message:
To answer your questions:

First, the easy: no clue about revising anything else. That's all way, way up in the air.

The harder: the revisions are pretty extensive in some parts, fairly minor in others. I'd say only really book 4 (formerly Blood of the Underworld) is the one I'd strongly recommend people read, given just how much I've changed and added. The others, while improved, should not require a re-read to understand what is going on in the final books 5 and 6.

Also, I'll be writing up quick primers on my website detailing what changes I made for people who have already read the books, that way they can see the tweaks and decide if they should reread or not, and if they don't, they'll still know what changes I made (particularly ones that might have any significant plot implications down the road).

data.message: Senke's death stays the same. The fix will be in Cost of Betrayal, not the other way around.

His death is sooo predictable this way. It would be way better, if Senke would survive the fight, get healed, then walk into a bar, and get into that brawl. A little bit like the real world, when random things can happen. Or a little bit like GameOfThrones. Nobody ever saw coming the massacre at the 'red wedding' for example. Especially not in the books...

Plus, the funeral in cost of betrayal would be more touching as well. IMHO

message: Thought you might like this, looks like someone upset Karak.

Okay guys, consider this the big WARNING:

The Shadowdance Trilogy, plus the Watcher's Blade, will be going off sale come July 1st from all venues. This is to pave way for the Orbit re-releases, which so far will be hitting:

Dance of Cloaks: October
Dance of Blades: November
Dance of Mirrors (formerly Death): December

So if you haven't finished it yet, and have no desire to wait, then please make sure to buy it before then. In case anyone was wondering, you will not lose these old versions from your Kindles/iPads and whatnot, they won't be deleted secretly in the night, etc. New readers simply won't be able to buy the old versions.

Now, all that being said, I should have some good news to post fairly recently, including a new short story collection focused on Thren Felhorn, as well as a look at the new Orbit covers (which are freaking awesome).

So yeah, that's it. I'm really excited about this, and come October when I can start blitzing you guys with sales and reviews and covers, well, I hope you will be too :-)

David

data.message: Graham, with the release of each book I'll be posting a primer listing all the significant changes to each book. But in terms of amount, I assure you, far more has changed than just titles. DoC had a complete overhaul, lot of plotlines tied up, a new scene with Zusa and Alyssa added, plus things like Zusa/Eliora switching places in two scenes, reworked order for chapters (what used to be chapter 1 is now chapter 3), lot of consistency tweaks to match later books in the Shadowdance series, better consistency in terms of timeline of events in the book, the Worm pops up in an additional scene, etc.

data.message:
Shadowdance 1-3 will still clearly be Shadowdance 1-3 (with A Dance of Death renamed A Dance of Mirrors).

The only potentially confusing part, and I'm sure we'll make sure this is noted in the description, is Blood of the Underworld. I've heavily changed a lot of its plot, added about 15k words of new stuff, and renamed it A Dance of Shadows, with effectively the Watcher's Blade now just considered books 4-6 of the Shadowdance series.
Thank you :) It sounds like it might be worth re-reading the new ones with all the new content anyway :)

I'll be posting a little primer with the changes to the various books when they're released, in case people who have read it before are curious. Book 4 is the only one I'd strongly push for even people who've read it before to read again.
Thanks again :D

I'd rewrite the prequels in a heartbeat is what I'd do. Anakin would have been a kind, loving, ambitious young jedi. Basically, he'd have started out as Haern, and the emperor would have been Velixar. Make the clone wars an actual rebellion of a slave class of clones, have the jedi be seen as aloof and failing to understand the real social problems lying underneath the rebellion (see my angels in HO6). Oh, and the gungans would have been a race given a single footnote about their brutal extermination at the hands of, I don't know, renegade wookies or something.

data.message:
Two things: one, I wrote CoB waaaaay before writing even DoC, and had a decent idea who Thren was.

*spoilers*
Two: Haern remarks upon this in CoB.

“He lied to me,” Haern whispered, staring at the body of his father....“He knew I was his son. Perhaps for all these years, he knew. Yet he still tried to kill me.”

So no mistake :-)
Lol... Must have missed that line when I double checked. Ill gladly be ok with my mistake of thinking that!
You're hardly the only one. This gets pointed out to me about once a month. I mean, I've screwed up plenty elsewhere, but dangit, this one I got right!

I think it's just because in BotU and DoC Thren clearly knows its Haern but in CoB he's like" oh, you're the watcher" when at the end of BotU they are getting ready to go to the stronghold together and Thren told Greyson that the watcher is Haern. I was hoping you'd hint at what's gonna happen in the next book of the Watchers Blade series;) (Thren gets his memories wiped or a coma or something) lol
Just don't let tarlak die! Lol

It's more fun than that. Again, Thren was lying when he reacted in CoB, so just discount that. As for Haern/Thren in the next book, it's a giant mind game with Thren pretending not to know who he is, yet still trying to figure out who his son has become, and whether or not he can be turned more toward his line of thinking.

Guys, I know I've been quiet lately, and you're probably wondering why I'm not posting tons of info about my newest release (given how I promised it to be, well, really really soon). Well, the thing is...it looks like my next few books (both Watcher's Blade Trilogy, and the Gods' War series) aren't going to be self-published by yours truly, but by two different, large publishers....

Exciting? Heck yes. Do I have more I can share? Not until ink's dry on contracts, and then I'll be shouting it out to the world. But for now, let's just say this is stupidly exciting.

data.message: There's a difference between an animated corpse and an actual trapped soul. I think he'd be okay with a few dozen zombies to fight for him.

SPOILERS!!! Oh so a trapped soul undead is an intelligent and more dangerous servant like Haern or that poor half orc who had his nuts blown up. I got the idea that zombies still have their soul from Cyrics army of undead with their souls trapped In their bodies, the ones he wanted to force to worship Karak. Guess Cyric was just unnecessarily mean...

Well, what If somebody asked Qurrah to do it so they could finish something they wanted to do after they died? Or if Qurrah had the corpse of somebody he really hated who was a powerful warrior and he knew they could help him save Tessana from some sort of danger?

Cyric's little army was because he had delusions of saving their souls by compelling their animated bodies to obey. So yeah. He was, uh, special in many horrible ways.

As for your ideas of what might make Qurrah change his mind: I guess we wouldn't know unless Qurrah's faced with such a situation. Which he may or may not. Depends on what horrible thing I do to the guy next :-)

message: SPOILERS!  So it says in the new Half Orcs book that Qurrah intends to never trap a soul in an undead body again. I wonder if Qurrah would stick to that resolution if he happened to be on the losing side of a battlefield and saw a loved one at risk? A few thousand zombies could turn a tide...

I just finished Broken Pieces and you throw another book my way. You really know how to feed a reading addiction. Is theer any chance we might see a book covering the misadventures of a certain yellow robed wizard?

Had it asked often, but I don't think Tarlak will ever carry a title on his own. I much prefer being able to bounce him around and off other characters. That said, he's always going to have an important role in the Half-Orcs.
@Richard T Webb we could use a Tarak book yes!  Especially of his early years, and another series about Deathmask's upbrining!

More more more, always more. But I don't waannaaaa. I wanna move forward, not write prequel series #17....

/whine

You do have a whole forest of Pesky Elves that you haven't touched on much. With the humans in chaos, I would think there's an opportunity out there for a little Elvish Growth beyond the woods they've been forced to occupy.

Few more books into the Half-Orcs I have a plan to bring them more to the forefront. I dabbled in their politics occasionally, and pretty significantly in Dance of Death. The Gods' War books, however, will feature a *lot* more elves in general, and will hopefully be what you're looking for.

Have you read Orson Scott Card's book on character development?  I would suggest it reading your works.  I would also suggest The Writer's Journey: Mythic Structure for Writers.  Trust me as a man who at 35 has read 1-2 books a week and am a walking library.

@ Rt Webb: funny thing is you discount the state the elves are in, and what the rest of that world is in.  Do you forget that the elves were forced into one small area in this world, scattered by one king burning down their realm, and another ignoring the delving into their territory by angelport?

@ Rt Webb they could come back, but do not forget the nature of elves, they have very few magic users left, they are on the point of genocide, and they are desperate. Dierdron could not get the elves to interfere in the last war, and now they face not only the angels, but their own goddess in human form of darkness in you know who, who is the balance tipper towards chaos!
*is starting to worry others know more about his own world than he does*

I've been thinking about this a bit as I've devoured the last four or five books, and I respectfully disagree with my compadre here. The things is, with other writers, you KNOW they won't REALLY kill certain characters, so any time they are in danger, the "fear" you feel for them is fake. I have seen you kill too many "don't go there" characters to be like that.

SPOILER ALERT: So I was TERRIFIED for Jerico when he got captured by the demons. Part of me was like, "There's no WAY DD would kill HIM off", but the other part of me figured, "Well, you said the same about her, and him, and him, and her, so..."
SPOILER ALERT: (Mind you, I wouldn't mind a few books on Haern's adventures in the afterlife, if you don't mind...)
It's a double-edged sword. People love that major characters can die...they just don't want those major characters to be the ones they really like. It's all good :-)

message:
So I enjoyed Half Orcs 6. The Angels are fascinating creatures. Now you ask for critiscism so... I thought it was a bit slow at the start FORGIVE ME MASTER!! It got real good about halfway once it started to build up steam. I can understand why though, time had to be given to setting up new conflicts and such. I look forward to the next on book now that there's momentum.

SPOILERS!

That bit where Ezekai went mad at the end was amazing. I've read stories with fallen angels before but I don't think I've ever seen anyone do the process of falling. Now maybe I'm just a conspiracy nut but there seemed something weird about those two situations with the people who had supposedly commuted crimes. It was all circumstantial evidence and paranoia but nobody had any doubts. Then the stranger who understands shows up with perfect timing right after Ezekai goes on his killing spree and Ezekai could apparently sense the villagers minds nearby until after he killed them but not the stranger. Could it all be the conspiracy of the stranger? Could he have done something to the villagers to whip them into a frenzy of paranoia and anger? Prehaps he haunted their dreams? If so, It all seems very Velixar....

message:
Attention iBookstore users: if you haven't noticed yet, nearly all of my books are currently missing from the store. That is because I'm replacing them with updated versions, and uploading directly to Apple myself (theoretically decreasing the time for new releases to go on sale there).

That said, Prison of Angels should go on sale at the same time the rest of my catalog becomes available. Also, every single review on those books (barring the two freebies, NoW and WoB) will have vanished. Even after discussing with customer service, appears that is just something I'll have to deal with. So if you've rated one of my books before, tossing another back up onto one of my older books would be much appreciated.

As for time estimate: seriously, it could be any day. Right now the books are being reviewed for quality control by Apple (as they have been since the 30th), and the second they approve it, it will immediately go on sale. Thanks for waiting semi-patiently. I know it's killing some of you :-)

data.message: Well, if it makes you feel any better, *spoiler spoiler* Darius does make a cameo in the sixth Half-Orc book...

Dave, thank you. Where can I go online to find out an interpretation of what was happening to Darius & Valessa in that last scene? I read it over, and over, and over again. My imagination and mind went in a million directions. Very confused. FANTASTIC READ but still...
Where can you go online? Well, you come right here, to me, and just flat out ask me what was happening, and what you're confused about. I do tend to be a reliable source in these matters.
(and do you mean Jerico and Valessa, or are you referring to two different scenes?)
Oops. Tried to back to my copy of the book to make sure that I got her name correct. And yes.
Sorry about that. I was not sure what was allowed online/FB/etc.

So here goes: WHAT was happening to Darius when the wings appeared? Was that Ashur? Was Darius being transformed? When (Valessa??) was immitating Jerico - she was NOT injured when Darius swung at her (no way, just no, no, no way), correct?

Forget fighting scenes, warfare scenes. What happened to/for/with Darius & his girl (thought it was Valessa), Jericho & his love... just sucked that what lived by the sword - died by the sword..... you know?! (help here, I really, really fell in love with this series..)
imitating. Sorry for typo.

Okay, I'll try to answer this as coherently as possible given how late it is here:

How things went down: technically Darius was to simply give his life so Jerico could live, without being hunted and stalked for years on end. That was his sacrifice, and it was freely made. However, Luther had the incredible wisdom/stupidity to insult Ashhur. So what was meant to be a sacrifice suddenly became a fiery lesson. Darius was given a momentary change into what he would one day become, gaining wings, strength, speed, and a healing of his body. Yet when it was all said and done, and Ashhur withdrew the power he'd given him, Darius had to once more survive on his own strength...which given the brutal punishment he'd taken, he couldn't. His sacrifice for Jerico remained.

As for Valessa: with her new form, she could only be hurt by the weapons of a paladin, be it Karak or Ashhur. So yes, Darius's glowing did hurt her, though not fatally, and nowhere near as badly as one of Karak would have done (given how she was basically composed of light near the end). That's why she didn't just get up and join in the fight. Valessa honestly expected to die there, and she felt it her due for what Darius had done for her (and an apt punishment for her own life). But when she survived, she went looking for Jerico, and followed him from afar as he returned to the ruins of the Citadel. But she knows him nowhere near as well as Darius, hence leaving him be.

Of course, she still has a beef with Luther. And if you read Blood of the Underworld, you'll find out several more characters do as well. She'll be returning in the second book of that, once I get back to it ;-)

Btw, if you loved the series, you might give the Half-Orcs a shot. Jerico was first introduced in the third book of it, and the second book features another paladin, Lathaar, and also goes into a tiny bit of detail about the Citadel falling. Plus the series very much revolves around the Karak/Ashhur conflict, just in a much broader scope.
Interesting. Did not know about that. Thought it might be a completely different storyline.
All of my fantasy novels are set in the same world, and roughly in the same time frame.
The Paladins series, for example, was intended as a prequel series to explain Jerico's backstory.

data.message: Pfft. Spam responses. So totally not what I do.

The Brent Weeks comment isn't too far off, really. I was about 1/3 through writing DoC when I read the Night Angel Trilogy, and it was like a light bulb going off in my head. So *this* was how you do it, I basically thought, and incorporated elements of things I liked, particularly the underworld, things that the story was desperately needing.

As for "do I go back" it'd help if I knew what you'd read. I'd written the first three Half-Orc books prior to DoC, which is where you can see a major step up in quality imho. Half-Orcs gives some people fits, but you should at least give the Paladins a shot. The final two books are something special.

message:
I sent this to your email (just in case it gets spammed I posted here. Sorry it's so long)
Just a fan who finished reading Blood of the Underworld (5 minutes ago) and wanted to write.... 
I have never written to any author before and don't expect a response but it would be like an autograph if you did (even if it's spam!) and really liked The Shadowdance Trilogy, especially the covers. The plain white is reminiscent of tattoo art which I enjoy.  I have read literally thousands of books in the sci-fi/fantasy genre (periods of unemployment and/or jail, plus my self imposed retirement at age 30 helped) I have to say YOU ARE GETTING REALLY GOOD.  In reading those thousands of books, I obviously read many bad ones. Even a good paragraph can justify 300 pages of trash. My opinion won't mean much, but I first thought that maybe you were a Brent Weeks wannabe. Not so. Since your getting so good do I go back? or just wait for the new? I think you are probably your harshest critic so I trust your judgement. Anyway keep up the great work! I have always wanted to start a book but I think I would just subconsciously re-write the best stuff from the best authors. I would like to know what you read (if you even have time to) and if you ever get a chance to read Bernard Cornwell's Saxon trilogy PLEASE DO IT! Uhtred may be the coolest Dane-raised priest slaughtering Brit to come along in that genre. I have got at least 5 of my friends to start reading books (instead of TV) just on that series. There is a scene in which the main character and a fellow named Staepa Snortor are chasing down some guys after battle and finishing them off when  Uhtred hears Staepa sneeze in between killing blows and asks if he has a cold. To which Staepa replies,".......Just read it. I can't stop laughing. Your awesome! -

Dave

message:
sent in a review to Amazon. Thought I'd share it here: 
The Broken Pieces is a very well written book. The character development and story treatment are perfect. David Dalglish has become My favorite author. His foes have depth and purpose, his heroes are perfect in their intentions and will to see through the worse of situations. Dalglish brings a very refreshing air of hope and redemption in our modern culture wasteland of apathy and despair.  In today’s market of all heroes being flawed, Dalglish gives us heroes that are truly worth looking up to.

data.message: I don't mind knowing if you find them, though it'd only really be best if you went by the digital copies. Because of cost/time/selling so few, the print copies tend to lag behind in terms of any typo corrections.

Digital is what I read most :) and easy to "highlight" on the kindle - The Old Ways pg 209 "especially if she should become emotional" when Darius is referring to Gregory - I have a 5 hr car ride today and your books are keeping me company the entire way :)
Hope I help you out with the car ride then :-)
Pg 274 - Cyric turned his blade - I believe you mean Darius?
Yup.

Yeah, there are at least one example of inserting the wrong name or gender in referencing a character. Your latest novels definitely have fewer hiccups though. :) Does your editor just look for typos or does he/she actually read through? Do you still make corrections even after the books are completed?

Yeah, I still make corrections even after the books are published (though people who have already purchased the book won't get those corrections). And my editor does read-through as well as typo hunting. It's just there's always going to be something that sneaks through.

message: If we find typos are you the kind of author that wants to know about them? I edit investigative reports so they stand out to me easily :) if so I'd gladly but all print copies of your books and re-read them

message: Ummm, couple of things... Thank you for making my first foray into reading self-published books, or as I like to call them guerrilla published, on amazon, you're an excellent author who has actually made me want to pick up the pen and get these ideas out of my brain!! Secondly, I really wanna win a mousepad! Lol

So while goofing around making mouse pads and phone skins, I've grabbed a few extras, and now I'd like to give some away. So in anticipation for the upcoming release of the sixth Half-Orc book, The Prison of Angels, I'm giving away two mouse pads featuring the cover art, plus another featuring Darius from Clash of Faiths (see the above pic, and my apologies for shoddy quality of said pic).

So what do you do to enter? Two things. One, go here (http://ddalglish.com/wp/?page_id=690) to sign up for my mailing list if you haven't already. I use this only for announcing new releases, so don't fear any spam. After that, just post a comment on Facebook in thread saying, well, anything. Tell me I'm awesome, say you want a mouse pad, insult my grandma, whatever. On the November 9th I will be randomizing the three winners, and sending messages via Facebook to the winners to confirm the email address is indeed in the mailing list.
Oh, and if the winners would prefer, I can sign the mouse pad before shipping. Just to, you know, up the sexy factor.

Good luck, thanks for playing, hope the winners enjoy the phat loot.

*edit*

Now also giving away a fourth mousepad featuring Zusa on the cover of A Dance of Cloaks!

An automated message from a successful subscription would have been nice. Or i did something wrong?
Istvan, no I think you did everything right. I can turn on a confirm email, if people really want one.

In my case, it's a 'good to have' thing, because I usually give myspammableaddress@corp.com in the subscribe field. Then I receive a confirmation e-mail from subscirption@fan.org. Then I redirect all e-mails from subscirption@fan.org to myrealemailaddress@corp.com. So, if somebody hacks in, and stoles a lots of data from fan.org (including my e-mail address), I still wont have any spam message on my real email address. If there is no confirmation e-mail, then I can't redirect the e-mail address until there is a message sent out from it, and ofc, I have to browse my spammable e-mail address as well... Long story short: can u provide me the sender address of the mail list, so I can redirect it?
Sure, one second.
Should just be ddalglish@yahoo.com
Thanks. :) That was fast :) One more question from out of nowhere: Have you ever thought about translating your books to different languages?
Sort of, but the cost of it would be incredibly high, for what would probably be very meager returns for a very long time.

Time for my go to list! This is based on the style of each of my books, the primary influences.

Half-Orcs: RA Salvatore (start with Dark Elf Trilogy)
Shadowdance: Brent Weeks (Night Angel Trilogy)
Paladins: David Gemmell (ton of good stuff, I'd start with Sword in the Storm).

data.message:
Aye, when I first conceived the idea of the Paladin series I was thinking short books, and also bouncing stories between Jerico and Lathaar, perhaps even going forward and backward significant leaps in time (to feature paladins from other time periods, even). Obviously that didn't happen, and since Lathaar and Jerico's story didn't intersect until Death of Promises, I can't really bring him into the story arc for the Paladins.

So for Lathaar, he does have at least one novel in him. If I do write it, it'll be the Fall of the Citadel, detailing a lot of the stuff he kind of gives Tarlak/Jerico a brief rundown of in Cost of Betrayal and Death of Promises.

Cool, thanks for the info. I had seen you mention Fall of the Citadel, but wasn't sure if that was going to be the book about Lathaar. Of course you realize that if you think that you have one book about him you'll probably actually have five. Then you'll have to rename the Paladin series, because both series will be about Paladins. Just don't say I didn't warn you. :P

It'll be either Paladins #0, or Paladins #5, when I do write it. It'll depend on the length, really. If it hits 100-120k length, I may just launch it as a stand-alone novel. And nah, the events/storyline in this one is pretty set, since it is an old novel I wrote in high school that's still in a shoebox in my closet.

OK, if you say so. I'm sitting here smiling, because I'm imagining a post from you a year from now that says "Well, I thought that this was going to be a stand-alone novel, but the characters felt otherwise. Lathaar demanded that I write a whole series about him, so blame Lathaar." :)
Hahahah
Given the way things have gone with me, yeah, there's always that chance, isn't there? History is on your side :-)

hehe. Of course, we all love it when the characters do that because the results are always so fantastic. <3 Looking forward to reading the next Half-Orc book and the Fall of the Citadel whenever it comes out. :-)

message: Hi David! I just wrote the first review of Broken Pieces over at B&N (5 starts of course). Your books just get better and better. I'm curious though. The Paladins series was originally supposed to be about both Jerico and Lathaar. (In fact, your web page still mentions Laathaar on the Paladins page). Will Lathaar star in his own series eventually, so we find out what happened to him before the Half-Orc series?

data.message: Awesome, Keith, you should enjoy. The books pretty much improve one after another, with the final two being some of the best I've ever written. I hope you enjoy!

message: Holy cow! Just finished Night of Wolves and I am absolutely in love with this series already. I have to be careful not to read too much on your page, for fear of spoilers, but I wanted to come and tell you how excellent I thought the series was so far. I devoured book one in a day, and believe the next three will share a similar fate!

data.message:
Awww. If it'd make you feel better, you can be a *little* mad at me. It's okay. I can take it :-)

And yeah, I really wanted Broken Pieces to feel like a total gut punch. No one, no one, who has read all four paladins books is going to forget Darius now, and honestly, I can't imagine any other way I'd have ended his story arc better than I did.

message:
**Spoiler Alert***
Just finished Broken Pieces. Once again, I couldn't put it down. 
I want to be mad at you. I want to yell at you and have a tantrum because you hurt me. You made me cry. You made me feel as if a piece of my heart has broken off. But damn, you write an amazing story. And there are so few authors who write with such passion that their readers feel the raw emotions of all of the characters. As much as I want to deny it, it was the right ending. I feel like you took a dear friend from me. But I know I'll read it again. Thank you.

data.message:
Anderson, the final book couldn't deal with Thren Felhorn because that conflict already takes place in the Half-Orc series. So if you view Haern vs Thren as the main storyline, then yes, Dance of Death is a side mission, if you will. However, I always viewed the series as focused around Haern and his growth as a character. In that sense, much of what he confronts in the third book is about defining who he is and what he's become.

If you wanted to, though, you could probably skip straight to Blood of the Underworld without being too lost. And Thren definitely has a presence in that one ;-)
The thing is that I like Haern but I expected a fight between Hearn and Thren. In other words if I want to know more about thren felhorn I would have to read half orc series. Is that correct.

Haern and Thren are introduced into the series in book 2. Major caveat: that book was written *before* the Shadowdance trilogy.

If you really want lots more of Thren, Blood of the Underworld is the next place to go.

James, consider this a spoiler for later books:

Luther vs Velixar *might* happen in the third Watcher's Blade book. It's not likely, but it could happen. And yeah, I was determined to flesh out the lore a lot more in this book. I think I leveled up in that ability this book :-)

Velixar would really want Luther dead if he heard all that talk about changing the priesthood. Poor Luther probably wouldn't do too well in a straight up fight with him either. It would be interesting to see them debate though.

I had an odd thought. If Luther is right when he theorized that the gods can be changed by mortal minds, then Karak could perhaps be getting pulled in two different directions by those who see him as a harsh but fair enforcer of law (like Darius used to) vs those who see him as a death god willing to cause great chaos to achieve lasting order(Velixar)Perhaps there could end up being two Karaks, or one Karak with a split personality driven mad by mortals.

The key thing is that with these priests and these faiths: they don't know for certain. Velixar could be speaking 100% truth. He could be delusional. Course, the Half-Orcs shows that Karak's not exactly puppies and rainbows, nor is Velixar some rogue unwanted priest in his eyes. And while it is absolutely true that the deities have changed since their initial war (all of which will be going into far more detail in that series of books when we get to it), the question is...why? Is it the priests? The worship? Time? The after-effects of the war?

Luther's explanation, while fairly accurate, may still be just him trying to come up with an explanation he prefers to explain what he sees. The other is that Karak is indeed mad, and is perfectly fine with what Cyric is doing. Or perhaps Karak is completely, totally powerless. But he doesn't want to believe either.

As for Velixar vs Luther: I don't think they'll directly fight...but look at the events in book 1...take a look at who is running the show, what the goals are, what they're preparing for. Ask yourself, what's Luther's endgame? And did I mention that this series is going to lead right up to Weight of Blood?

message:
Okay, I promised a timeline so here it finally is. Given how I constructed it *after* all of these books were finished, I reserve the right to correct dates as needed should I have made a mistake :-)

But for those wanting to see exactly how everything goes chronologically, this should hopefully clear things up a little bit.

For the Shadowdance Trilogy I tried to keep things as grounded as possible, and the effects of magic and monsters to a minimum. In that regard, Dieredon's bow has often been called...unrealistic :-)

So out it went. That, and now I have an easy explanation for when him and Haern fight, no one can claim them the better fighter since Dieredon was fighting with a handicap.

Hah, the pressure's definitely from readers. I got two emails in three days asking for a timeline so they could read the books chronologically, and the more books I crank out, the more common the question's becoming.
Who was it that said "always leave them wanting for more"

Lol I was one who asked as well. I started with the half or series, seeing it was the first books published. With the Paladins and Shadow dance trilogy out I searched everywhere to try and see which ones I should have started with first. Now I know, but it definitely won't hurt your new readers. 

In other words its about time, David!

:D

I think my series are all capable of being read individually, so I try not to tell people a clear cut "must read first" book. But if going chronologically, Dance of Cloaks is first, and that tends to be a good opener for everyone.

Kinda hard to read them all in chronological order when you haven't quite finished the Watcher's Blade trilogy yet...it's kinda like missing out on the middle of a movie. The beginning's great, the ending is wonderful, but what happened in between? Not that it's stopped me from re-reading again...

I really like how each of your series are complete stand alone's and yet they also all tie in together with subtle tones. Personally having read all your books more than once I don't need a timeline but I can see how one would be usefull for newcomers to your Legacy. As for maps, would love to see some more as it means the possibility of creating an authentic  D and D universe in Dezrel much possible !

David, have you ever found yourself going "hang on, if my characters go from here to there they will have to pass through the evil forest of cannibalistic monkey elves! Should I have them go around or have them fight the monkey elves?" Probably going to happen sooner or later as you keep churning out books. :P

James, I'm not yet to the desperation point of ideas that I'm ready to have them travel through the forest of evil monkeys. Now the forest of rodents of unusual size, now that I might have to one day do.

Well every fantasy world needs giant rats for inexperienced adventurers to kill.

I was more getting at how as you get maps and stuff done, whether you think the map and the locations of things will start to influence things more.

Like "Oh If they travel this way they will pass the ruins of the Citadel, maybe the characters should stop to have a look."
Probably not. More that the reverse happens. I have them go somewhere there's a blank spot on a map, and I think "well something's gotta be there" and then I fill it in. And then my map is obsolete.
When it comes to Shadowdance, there's a 5 year gap between book 1 and 2, and a two year gap between book 2 and 3.

Going off the top of my head here, but from Dance of Death to Watcher's Blade trilogy is 2 more years. From there, the trilogy will take up about six months I believe, leading into the very beginning of Weight of Blood.

message:
For those who've been wanting it (and I know there's plenty) I'm working on a permanent timeline for my world on my website so everyone can see where each book takes place. Hopefully in a week or so it'll be up.

As for why there hasn't been one yet: when I read books, for the most part I completely ignore all dates and whatnot that are chapter headings and whatnot. It's never been something I care about. So when I started writing these books, since it wasn't something I cared about, I didn't do it (just like with maps). Buuut....just like with the maps, it's become a large enough issue I need to suck it up and get it all worked out.

So that's about it. Return to your regularly scheduled Facebooking experience.

message:
All the books thus far have entertained me like nothing else.  I was a die hard Lee Child and Cussler fan with the military style combat and weaponry.  I merged into new catagories following bradford's young samurai series.  After that was done, I followed it up with some Merz and Vampires...then to true fantasy with your novels.

I must say Haern is a great character to follow, as well as Jericho!  I love the battles of faith, and how much people are devoted to it.  I am not a big religious person, but I think it makes for a very captivating story line!  This type of writing reminds me of some books by Karen Hancock (legends of the Guardian King Series) if not read...they are extremely fun.

Thanks again for making reading such an enjoyable experience.  I love self published works, as they seem to show off many writers creativity.  Albeit some have grammar issues, some have underdeveloped characters, but all in all...the reading is what makes it fun!

More Zusa, More Jericho, More Darius.  A spin off series with the Angels would be sick (something about their realm)

data.message: Worst I've endured at a hospital is a broken collarbone, so I can't imagine what you're going through. I'm glad that I can help in anyway. Hope your surgery went well, and enjoy hanging out with Haern in Shadowdance :-)

message:
So, I've been struggling with an autoimmune disease  known as Cogan's Syndrome since late December. It caused me to have severe pain in my eyes (which are better now), extreme constant vertigo, and hearing loss in both ear since mid-February. Left ear is completely deaf. Since I haven't been able to work due to the hearing loss or drive, I've been doing a lot of reading! Mostly fantasy. I know I told you the other day when I posted on here, but I just wanted to let you know that the half-orc series was such a pleasant surprise and is easily becoming one of my favorite fantasy series. You are such a fantastic writer and your books just get better and better. 

Yesterday I had surgery for a cochlear implant for my left ear. While at the hospital, my wife bought me The Shadowdance Trilogy as a recovery gift. I can't wait to dive in. Thanks for for writing such intriguing stories and for helping me get through these tough times.

-Max

data.message: Tarlak's attitude is modeled after my older brother. How he looks is modeled after my older brother's character from Ultima Online, for those who remember it.
including the yellow robe?  I was thinking Gauntlet for the yellow robe..

In UO, one of the cheapest ways to define how your character looked was to grab a plain gray robe (which you gained every time you died) and then dye it using a dye tub. My brother's wizard always ran around in a yellow robe with a black cape. So that's the big secret behind Tarlak wearing yellow.
All this time I thought it was Tarlak's amazing self confidence in his manhood LOL
Well, that too. I've bounced around a few in-story explanations, but not one I'm satisfied with enough to reveal. I figure it has to be very traumatic, or very, very goofy. One of the two.
