A post by yours truly discussing self-publishing, for any that might be interested.

data.message: ... by writing really good books! Duh! :)
Well, I like to pretend that helps significantly ;-)
Great article. Thanks for posting it David.
Awesome!
I wonder if ebooks and self publishing makes traditional publishers nervous...

Great article.  I too was trained to believe that self-publishing was the death sentence for writers, which was why I never pursued that route.  It wasn't until a few weeks ago, when I read your Half-Orcs series that my mind has shifted gears.  Regardless of how many/few books I sell, I owe you a huge thank-you.

Well, Im a reader, not a writer. I almost did not read your article because I will probably never try to publish anything, and I thought it would not be interesting... But I did, because YOU wrote it. The article was really interesting, because to me, you can turn even the most mundane subject into a story :) Your writing style hooked me in The Weight of Blood, and I just had to have every book. I am so glad you didnt wimp out, or let professor's and publisher's advice make you change your stories, or (GOD FORBID) not write your books. I am definitely one of those who devours your work, and I have spread the word to my friends. Lucky for me you write a lot, and you write fast!! You are one of my all time top 10 authors, and I have read hundreds of books in my life, probably even thousands. Please, tell your wife thank you from all your faithful readers for helping you with the idea of self publishing. All those people who told you elves and orcs wouldnt sell are probably kicking themselves hard. I hope they are, because they couldnt have been more wrong. There is a HUGE fanbase for this type of work. Now get back to writing. Anything is fine, as long as I get to read it soon :D

Melody, I don't need to tell my wife Thank You. She knows. I spoil her a ton with all that fancy-shmancy e-book money. And I'm glad all of you got something out of it. I was worried I was just rambling incoherently.
And that's what I'm saying. One mans incoherent ramblings are another's enthralling epic tales :D
i may have to try it myself one day if i can ever figure out how to make the ideas in my head look half decent on a page lol

Certainly not the easiest of professions to be successful at, but the amount of people making a living has drastically increased over just two years. If you're willing to put in the hard work, it can be tremendously rewarding.
It's tremendously rewarding for your fans too! I am very glad you took the chance and put your work out there :)
Big three influences: R.A. Salvatore, Brent Weeks, and GRR Martin.

David, I think your real problem lies with the fact that you've given us a glimpse of this chaotic, angry world & shown us that, despite every obstacle, there are still some fairly decent people doing more than just surviving. That is an awesome temptation to leave your world of petty woes & escape into someone else's horror. It is very addictive & hard for one man to keep up with the supply. 

Lucky for me that I came to your library after Half Orcs & am frantically preparing for baby #2 any day now so I've been mostly able to read solely your books without a lag. Soon I'll exhaust your library & need another fix though. Hope you have some help to keep up with the demand. :)>
I'll try to be patient, in the mean time. Not one of my strong suits though.
Heh heh, you can keep insisting I crank these out, but I feel bad for someone just discovering my little world twenty years from now. "I have to read *how* many books??"

Lol. It'll be awesome! They'll take a paid vacation to sit in their library for 2 weeks with an average of 3 hours of sleep & see how many stories they can pack away. It will definitely be hard to re-enter the real world though.  Hee, hee. So worth it!

data.message: Probably just over-analyzing. I don't know near enough about autism to have tried to make a character have it. I'll definitely give you credit for an interesting idea :-)  The main thing I tried to convey was an intelligent child put through rather extreme circumstances that severely affected his development socially. While most kids would have been playing with friends their age, he was learning breathing techniques and how to hide in shadows.
Yay for credit!

It's what I do.
Prefer that to a reader just kinda skimming along catching little, and showing no interest beyond the surface, that's for sure :-)

message:
Okay so spoilers for shadowdance....Very strange question and im probably overanalysing things but its been nagging at me.

The first thing you describe of Haern is how extremely quiet he is as a boy in shadowdance. I think Thren mentioned you might only get nine words in a day out of him?

Haern is very intelligent.

He has a lot of passion hiding beneath his cool visage.

He seems to lack social skills and can be very blunt with people.

He also is very skilled in battle and stealth, I could consider him a savant.... Is Haern Autistic? He does seem to fit with my limited understanding of Autism.

The way Haern is could be explained by his upbringing just as easily, It was hardly normal after all. But the bit about him being so quiet as a boy is what has me wondering mostly.

data.message: Glad you're enjoying the Alyssa/Nathanial/Zusa storylines, because for me, that's the one I have the most freedom with. message:
MINOR SPOILERS DO NOT READ IF YOU HAVEN'T FINISHED BLOOD OF THE UNDERWORLD!

I just finished 'Blood of the Underworld.' I'm madly, deeply, irrevocably in love with Haern have been since the Half-Orcs books. I literally cannot wait for the second book. I will be writing a review on Amazon. Seriously dude. Best ever! Secondly, Zusa is almost as amazing as Haern, thank you for creating a lesbian character (in a sense) whose sexuality isn't ever questioned it is just part of who she is. Finally, Alyssa and Nathaniel, I typically HATE noble born characters in fantasy novels, but I love these two!! By the end of the book I was screaming for Zusa to run! I hope this isn't the end for them. Thank you so much for your continued writing and how much love you give your fans!

(They are always in their "sunset", or not even close to where they were before the "Great Wars", or something similar...and no one ever tackles the spectacle of the "before"... even Salvatore's Drizzt series talks about the Elves the least of all (except the Dark Elf Trilogy, which I loved)!!!

Well its not a logic Id agree with personally. Karak seems to be obsessed with order from what ive read. Is Ashur equally obsessed with mercy or are your gods actually sane and not hellbent on furthering whatever they represent?
Might be getting into stuff you dont want to talk about so dont worry if you dont :P

Thinking of tweaking/delving into some of that with the final Paladin book, but particularly books 6 and 7 of the Half-Orcs. For me, the opposite end would be so thoroughly protecting the entirety of the population to the point that the ability to have free will starts being eroded.

Yeah well there is the fact that there is a heaven and hell in your world. Really the extremist form of mercy for an ashur follower in your world would be through force and manpulation make a true believer out of someone and then immediately kill them, so that they can go to the golden realm right? It wouldnt be a mercy to send someone to the abyss! Technically the person doing this though would have blood on their hands, so it would have to be someone willing to damn themselves or hypocritically planning to seek redemption later. Kinda like how that villain assasin guy in the Serenity movie was motivated to make a paradise of the universe through the federations control but accepted that he would never be allowed to live in it because he was a monster.
sorry for the text wall lol.

Basically, what I'm going to approach in Half-Orc book 6 is the dilemma of having actual, you know, angels flying around acting like a police force. There's going to be problems, especially when I start getting blood on the hands of a few of the angels.
I can imagine they will turn the the people against each other quite a bit. Some people would be willing to accept the angels word as law simply because they are angels.
But James,  a large minority (haha) feel law is synonymous with bad things. There is going to be trouble when the angels become cops. I am looking forward this.
Yeah it will be interesting.

message: Gotta say, your books are some of the most exciting and liberating works I've ever read. It's hard this day and age to find a good "Fantasy" series with memorable characters and an enticing plot. Throughout each book (Especially the main series) I hardly ever set them down from start to finish. The brothers' story kept me hooked  almost from the beginning. Villains as well are some of my favorite things in stories, and man you nailed them. I loved (er...hated?) each and everyone of'em, and the payoffs only made everything that much better. You've been a great inspiration to me, glad to have books like yours to go to, and will be waiting eagerly for what you've got coming!

message:
So in case someone missed the announcement earlier: I'm currently working on Blood of the Underworld, first book of a new Haern trilogy. It'll have a lot in common with Shadowdance, with a few key differences.

One: over-arcing plot between all three books with little time gap between them (compared to the 5 year, then 2 year, gaps in SD). I want to write what is effectively one very big story broken into chunks.

Two: this will connect *everything*. If I pull this off, I will have characters from the Half-Orcs, the Paladins, and Shadowdance all having their moment to shine. Now I know I'm guilty of doing this all the time, but I want it to be even more important (while still doing my best to not have any other series be required reading). But as a tantalizing idea: Haern meeting Darius? Oh yes. If I can make it happen, it will happen.

Three: not so much a difference, but more of a goal here, and that is to bridge the last of the time gap between the end of Dance of Shadows and the beginning of Weight of Blood.

Four: I'm just going to flat out acknowledge Zusa is just as important as Haern in the story itself. Her role will be about as vital in this series, particularly Blood of the Underworld, as it was in Dance of Death. Not a major change, exactly, but something to look forward to for those who like her. (Oh, and she'll be on the cover of the first book, too. Gotta stick with tradition, at least one more time!)

As for the story itself: It's a combination of threats descending upon Veldaren, all being masterminded by an unknown individual. Guilds from other cities are moving in against the current thieves. Mercenaries from half a continent away are being paid to hunt down the Eschaton. A long lost member of Alyssa's family has returned to challenge her authority over the family wealth. A man named Lord Victor Kane has declared his own private war against the Underworld, threatening the weak truce Haern's set in place. Last of all, a mysterious killer targeting both the Spider Guild, and Alyssa Gemcroft's family, removing the eyes of his victims, replacing them with silver coins, and then writing strange messages on the walls with the victim's blood...

Through it all, Haern is basically trying to keep the chaos to a minimum, and find out who is pulling all the strings.

So that's Blood of the Underworld. Should be finishing in a day or two, and have the completed artwork soon as well. Other than that, it'll be editing, more editing, and then formatting. Hoping for a  late April release.

Time for another touchy-feely post. Just got a few more updated numbers from various marketplaces, did some math, and found out I've crossed 200,000 sales over the past two and a half years. Just...unbelievably amazing. And since you all here are probably my most hardcore of fans, I want to thank you in particular, for everyone you've told of my stuff, for every hapless friend whose hands you shoved my books into.

Given how this was just a wing and a prayer when I first started, I can't be any more honored to have so many of you willing to be entertained by this boring white guy in Missouri. Thank you, so much. I'm truly blessed. Hopefully the best is yet to come, and I can keep delivering the most tragic, exciting, bloody, psychotic, over-the-top stories for you all for many, many years.

data.message:
I'll never use that love all my children excuse. Any author who says that is lying.

Favorite book: The Old Ways.

Iconic scene: When Harruq goes out alone to face Qurrah halfway through Shadows of Grace, and all the other characters are rushing out to protect him.

Favorite char: Tarlak. He's just so fun, and so easy to write.

Attention char: Tessanna. Always felt like she's had the most depth of any of my characters, and undergone so much transformation. Also a blast to write, allows me to go so dark at times. Thought she'd be my breakout character, honestly, or at least far more controversial.
Tarlak?  Really?  Poor Osric, we hardly knew thee...
Tarlak can simultaneously burst people into flame, or threaten to turn them into the opposite sex with a pink wand. Maybe I'm just immature, but I love 'em.

David do to have any plans to further define the magic system you're using?  Your casters seem to come out of a d&d mold; but don't fit exactly into the system of prepared spells and books.  Likewise they don't weave like aes sedai, drink metal or tap into nodes......  Your thoughts?

And I do really like how you've set different forms of magic apart.  I.e. necromancy is separate and significantly different from the magic that Tarlak and Aurelia use...  Deathmask's shadow magic being another example...
Tess and Tarlak rock!!

best moment for me: (Spoiler!!!) in Shadows of Grace, the scene where the parade of victims is brought before Jerico, standing broken and in tears, and they begin to tell him 'Ashhur loves you" before they're killed. i'll admit that i shed a few tears of my own. it was a very powerful scene.

Nicholas, I'm not much of a world-builder (especially compared to some of the greats). Generally the strength of a caster is a combination of an innate strength and their training to use said strength (kind of like a muscle). I've found it easier just to hint at various components required, whether verbally, hand motions, or actual spell components, and let readers fill in their gaps themselves. It's not important HOW Tarlak cast the fireball, in my opinion, just what happens after he does, and who gets burned.

And Dave, yeah, that scene with Jerico is another of my favorites. That defined his character forever in my mind.

SPOILER!!!

That whole part with Jerico was amazing. Seeing Velixar and  Tessana test his faith like that, I thought "oh yes they are going to have Jerico turn into a dark paladin"

When he didn't... Well, I was pretty darn surprised, It's a sign of a good writer when that many books in and he's still surprising you.
Especially after that scene, I could never have Jerico turn (what the heck could I do worse to him?). I'd be more likely to kill 'em than turn him to a dark paladin.

message: I was hoping you were thinking about a video game tonight as I finished book 4. And I'm thrilled to see you posting about it.

data.message: In a fair fight? Aurelia. Problem with Deathmask is actually getting a fair fight...
I really like Deathmask. He reminds me of my old oblivion character, who was a sneaky mage who was head of the thieves guild. Thing was, that guy was also a vampire.

He'd sneak up behind someone and hit them with a 100 points of damage every second for 10 seconds lightning on touch spell that I made. Drain his entire mana bar in one go, but not much in the game could survive it.

Goal when creating Deathmask was to make a character that was like Aurelia or Tarlak, yet with no moral code or squeamishness when it comes to killing people. Same time, I didn't want yet another necromancer or priest.

So basically, he ended up as a World of Warcraft Warlock.
Well as long as he doesn't go summoning any demons!
I guess nice guys don't apply fire directly to people's faces, do they?

Tough crowd! Most authors release  ONE book every year or two if you are fortunate . I am extremely impressed with the speed and variety of David's books. 
Although... I don't think he's mortal. 
1) Great books at lightening speed
2) Responding to emails and fan sites personally
3) Married with a (beautiful) daughter and another child impending 
4) Interacting / role playing with friends and a brother who must be awesome
5) Creating a gaming system for the world of Dezrel
6) True insight into the way people feel  ie women and minorities (I read the passage about why Ghost paints his face to my friends, then showed a pic of D to them. They were blown away. We had a 2 hour discussion and he got 5 new fans)
There is not enough time to sleep or eat. He is not human. I'm thinking a god, or at least a high ranking angel.

data.message: Haha. I was reading Chronicles of Amber while writing Sliver. I'm sure that was completely, totally, 1000% coincidental, though.
The fact that it's the same name makes me so much more of a fan then I was before, so awesome!!!  So when does Findo show up?

Actually, while I was reading Amber around the same time, I don't believe that's why I named 'em that. I think it was a tiny, tiny homage to one of the funniest movies of all time: Gamers 2, Dorkness Rising.

http://www.amazon.com/Gamers-Dorkness-Rising-Matt-Vancil/dp/B000MR9EQM/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1329709276&sr=8-1
Alright well now I like you less then before.  But a small price to pay for the awesome that is chronicles of amber....  Speaking of I need to reread those.
This while thing does beg the question; have you places names or character into your books as references to other stories or people? If so; can you share?  Also, I have a theory about tarlak...

Nah, Tarlak's a creation of my older brother, through and through. His crazy yellow mage was running around in the days of Ultima Online.

And you wouldn't like me less if you actually watched Gamers 2, btw. You'll be thanking me a billion times over instead.

And to answer your question: yes. All the friggin' time. Favorite songs, lyrics, jumbled references to other literary works, even the names of fellow indie authors who are friends of mine. They tend to die the worst deaths. It's a competition between us all.
Lol, that freakin awesome.  I was sure Tarlak was a dnd character or yours from way back...  There goes my theory.
Well, it was my brother's. That's gotta be close enough for half-credit.
So what's next after this?  No more half orcs, the other two were trilogies right?  Where are we going now?
Also: I've finally decided to buy an ebook reader, any recommendations on other indie writers of fantasy?  Like a top three?

Currently writing a new Haern trilogy that'll bridge gap between Dance of Death and Weight of Blood. As for other indie fantasy writers, the most obvious is a friend of mine, Daniel Arenson and his Song of Dragons trilogy.

He's near the top of my list of guys to look into.  What about creations beyond Dezrel?  Entire new worlds?  New continent?  Sorry about picking your brain, maybe this is more info then you'd want to give.  But i think we're all curious.
Between this new trilogy, finishing the Paladins, and continuing the Half-Orcs, plus the Gods War co-op books, I don't plan on leaving Dezrel anytime soon.
Continuing half ors whaaaaaaaaaaa?
Yup yup. Always meant to.
Damn it; so many more questions to ask, but I feel like I need to finish redemption before I can..
Okay sold. I am buying your books. ;)

Hi David,

data.message:
I once read a book where the entire thing was having the gritty mercenary mock the paladin, how he got his robes white, the pointlessness of honorable combat. Of course, the paladin was stuck up, holier than thou, the first to doubt, and of course, eventually revealed to have no faith in his deity.

Ticked me off so much, I swore to never, ever portray a character, good or evil, in such an insulting way. Paladins should be awesome, dangit, not men with sticks up their butts (or as the fantastic movie Gamers 2: Dorkness Rising put it, "Oh no, a babysitter!")
That paladin sounds like a massive strawmen for someone to attack religion from your description. Gotta hate strawmen.

Some people want to be Han Solo. I always wanted to be Obi-Wan. I'm cool with either, even cool with Han Solo poking fun at hoakie religions and ancient weapons...so long as the narrative is still respectful.

data.message:
Step 1: read the authors who you do like, and you know can do combat.

Step 2: figure out what the heck they're doing right.

I'd strongly suggest giving one of R.A. Salvatore's books a try. His combat is fantastic. The main thing is to try and get the reader into the feel of the fight. Use as many hard, oomph words as you can (crack, smash, slash, cut, slice, slam, smack, etc). Dwell on the fear of the moment. Have the reader feel the exhaustion in the fighter's arms, the fear that the next cut will be the one they fail to block.

As for how descriptive you are in the actual block/parry, that is up to you, and should suit how important the fight is. We don't need every cut and slash for Hero vs Minion #23423 but if it is the main villain, let it play out a little longer.

Lol. Thanks. I'm a pretty big fan of Salvatore.
I guess I just need to practice a lot. I'm fairly decent at everything else, I think. It's just difficult for me to imagine conflict on large scales, and I always go into too little or too much detail. Oh, well. I've been working on this thing on and off since I was twelve. A little bit more work won't kill me, right?
Getting it right certainly isn't easy. I'm, like, twelve books in or whatever and I'm still trying to figure out what the heck I'm doing.

I work on stuff on and off. I started most of it in middle school when I had no life, and now that I'm working on college stuff I've slacked off a little. I don't really have much hope of getting anywhere with it, but who knows. Perhaps I shall one day.

message: Do you have any advice on writing battle scenes? I'm in the process of trying to revise a book a wrote a few years ago, and have realized that there is much to be desired in terms of conflict description. I'm just horrible at making anything intricate enough to keep up suspense. >.<

Everything's very tentative right now, but I'd much appreciate as many answers from all of you as I can get. It's been a dream for a long while now to have a video game, of any type, based on my characters and world. I have a possibility, but the cost would be fairly steep. If there seems to be significant interest, I'll move the project forward to an actual planning stage.

Let's see, just off the top of my head...scene with Aullienna at end of CoB I listened to Offspring's So Far Away on loop, whole beginning of Death of Promises is heavily inspired by Sober from Tool, nearly every fight between Harruq and Qurrah has So Cold by Breaking Benjamin playing. As for Haern vs Harruq...hrm. Harruq did stand up to a deity at the end, but at the same time, Haern's just awesome. On pure skill, it's still Haern, but given Harruq had powers of a deity, magic swords, and was even trained by Haern, I'd say he'd come out on top. Barely. And plenty wounded.

data.message: You're welcome, Linda. I struggled horribly trying to decide what was best, but for now, I'm going to hope both the Nook and iBookstore continue to grow, and I can get some more attention there. Little messages like this certainly help :-)

I've found that the Half-Orc series is just too dark for some people I know, so now I'm recommending that they start with the pally series or the Haern series. Actually, I think I would have enjoyed the Haern series more if I'd read it before I read the Half-Orc series. It was just a bit weird to read those books after the events in the Half-Orc series. (I don't want to say too much more since it would involve spoilers for those who haven't read the whole series yet).

By the way, I'd love to make a few comments about things I liked in your books, but hesitate to talk about some of them since they contain spoilers. Do you have a spot somewhere for people to post comments that include spoilers? I looked at your website, but didn't spot a forum or anything like that.
You can post here, just put a big *SPOILER WARNING* at the very top  so people can choose to skip over it if they wish.

OK :)  *SPOILER WARNING*

I noticed that there have been some comments about what a great character Darius is (I agree). However, you said in a comment below that you either need to kill him off or explain why he didn't show up in the Half-Orc books. It seems that it would be a problem to leave him alive, since both the paladins believe that there are only 2 of them left.

However, I have an idea that I'd like to offer up. If you kill him off in the Paladin series, could he have been sent back as one of the angels in the Half-Orc series? I realize that the angels were the original followers of Ashhur, but perhaps an exception was made for Darius, so he could continue fighting for Ashhur after all the harm he did as a paladin for Karak. That way, he could appear in the follow-up series to the Half-Orcs.

I've actually had someone suggest similar, except for Haern. Now it'd make more sense for Darius, since to be part of that one-shot initial arrival of angels, he'd have already been dead (whereas Haern was kinda still alive and kicking). More likely, a lot of the new angel characters in the HO continuation will be characters from the Gods War collaboration I'll be working on soon, since it'd make sense a lot of those initial soldiers/priests/faithful would have become angels.

Now, the biggest reason I'm hesitant to bring Darius (and Haern) back as an angel (again, assuming he dies in the first place) is that it almost feels like a cop out. If I kill someone, they need to stay dead, since I've already had plenty come back as undead, and even Qurrah's case, life to dead to undead to alive again. If people don't trust me to leave a character dead, I'll be like a comic book, unable to really get the true emotion and shock of it (Oh ho hum, Batman 'died'. Yeah. Okay. I give it two months before he's alive again).

Anyhoo, when it comes to Darius, I won't cheat. He'll die heroically, if he dies. If he lives, then I'll find a way to explain where the heck he was during the Gods War. Heck, for all I know, Paladins #5 might be just that, following Darius through those few years. Could also make it a quick novella, just for fans of the series. I've got a lot of options to ponder, and some time before I begin writing the fourth Paladin book, so I'll keep mulling this stuff over in my head.

That makes sense. I was thinking somewhat the same thing actually, but wasn't sure if coming back as an angel was really coming back as "alive". (Are angels alive in the sense that we mean alive? After all, all of the angels were presumably dead humans at one time, right?)

Of course, I guess that Darius could have an "Enoch experience" and come back as an angel, but that seems like even more of a cop out to me than dying and coming back. :)

At any rate, I'll trust your judgment on this one. I love the turns and twists that your plots make, and I'm sure that you'll do a much better job of figuring out what to do than I would. :)
Glad to know you trust me. And Darius's fate is pretty much in his hands, not mine. He's ignored everything else I've told him to do.
lol. Well, I hope he makes good decisions. :)
I love reading some of the other readers comments. my thought on this one is .... does anyone really STAY dead ??? everyone is alive and well in my mind!!

Just my two cents but Darius does not need to be dead to explain why he is not in the half-orc series the world is a big place and for all we know Ashur has him off doing something important…  The Wedge is a largely untapped part of your story that I’m sure could account for Darius being missing, even to the point that Jerico thinks he is dead but is very much alive!!!  But of course this is all up to David, he might just kill him anyway hehe.
No, he doesn't need to be dead, but I do have to come up with a solid, viable, non-cheating explanation. We'll see :-)
No pressure right?
Oh no. Not at all. Not even close. Not like anyone likes Darius.
You might be  right who would miss him really?  Wonder how your email box would look after that kill if you did that.

*SPOILER ALERT*

About equivalent to when I killed *SPOILER ALERT AGAIN* Haern and then brought him back as undead.

I still get yelled at. A lot.
But would you change it?
What, H dying? Not for the world. I had too much fun with him in book 5 as a bad guy.

I must say: I have read several similar comments about something between Haern and Zusa. I definitely felt there was a connection between the two during Death but, as a woman, I really see it more of a mutual respect between their commonality of loner awesome assassin types. No love interest there. I think Zusa could love but not someone of the same profession or perhaps skill as her. Finally convinced my dad to get a kindle, and I have to tell you, your books went a long way in convincing him. When I told him how much I enjoyed the Half-Orcs, he ran to a bookstore and couldn't find them... So yay!!! I think he's even getting my grandfather one too!! Nicholas, if you know anyone with an e-reader, see if you can convince them to loan it to you for a week. I think you'll be surprised at how quickly certain things will grow on you. Never needing to mark your page, never needing to hold the book open, never adjusting it to weird angles to try and get the light to hit it just right, the lighter weight, having your entire library on hand at all times, adjusting font size to your comfort level, getting cheaper books, getting free books, instantly obtain whatever book you buy the moment you click the buy button...it's all pretty dang fine, especially when you can get one for $79 compared to what they were only a year ago.

I an reading your novels down under via Kindle on iPad. Gotta say...you should be charging more!!!! Please don't under value your writing. I am reading another writers trilogy at the same price point and it is like chalk and cheese. Yours is a bargain even at double the $$.

@ Nicholas... I said the exact same thing. My husband surprised me with one, downloaded Elantris by Brandon Sanderson on it so I could try it out and after about 5 minutes of getting used to the Kindle I was hooked. It goes everywhere with me now!!! And I have my entire book collection right in front of me. No more searching for that one book I'm just dying to read and not finding it.
Thanks Mick, but trust me, I'm doing quite fine on money. Just accept the bargains as my own little thanks :-)

data.message:
Depending on which books of mine are your favorites...

Shadowdance: GRR Martin's Song of Ice and Fire, and Brent Week's Night Angel Trilogy.

Half-Orcs: Salvatore, but you got that covered.

Paladins: David Gemmell.
Those are the heavy influential ones. Also, if you like Half-Orcs, you might hunt down the old Hickman & Weis novels, starting with Dragons of Autumn Twilight.
Will make a note of those for when i have finished your books
I've read song of ice and fire and night angel trilogy really enjoyed both series. I'm going to look into David gemmell and Hickman and weis. Thanks!!
Gemmell is awesome!  Look for Legend, it was his first, and best in my opinion.
I don't know, his Troy books are fantastic.

I haven't read those yet; after his death I set about gathering his entire library and as Christmas gifts my mother got me the Troy books in hardcover.  But I haven't gotten to them because I dislike hardbacks...
Any other favorites of his?
I really enjoyed the first two of his Rigante...
I haven't read as much of his stuff as I should. Did finish the first of his Jon Shannow novels, and  that guy's awesome, too.
Joe Abercrombie is something you all might like if you enjoy the darker fantasy!!
He's one of those authors I keep telling myself I'll read this century. I really gotta start reading more.
I head his First Law book and didn't really get into it, I think maybe I expected it to be something other then what it was.  But his new one, "Heroes" looks interesting.
I re-read DOC. I was too stressed to fully enjoy it the first go round, and the volume of characters was overwhelming. This time Gileas was like an old (disgusting) friend. Yuck.

*spoiler spoiler spoiler*

My editor was *furious* with what happened to the Worm. Wanted him to return in all three novels. Consider that another idea my wife vetoed, pretty strongly, too.

Robin Hobb's Farseer trilogy is pretty good. It definitely met my expectations for an epic fantasy series. Which by the way Mr. Dalglish, I would love to read an epic by you. Not saying you don't meet "epic" standards with your creation of Dezreal, but I mean like a flippin door stopper of a book. You pickin up what I'm puttin down?

Which one was the Farseer trilogy?  I read the first and third of her trilogies and Fitz is one of my all time favorite characters.  Even though in every book she leaves him laying in a ditch, bleeding, believing he's betrayed everyone he's ever loved.  Damn that woman was harsh.
By the way, I know who Captain Wookie is, it's in her acknowledgements and I know him.  You're jealous right?

Actually now that I think about it, if you published the Half Orcs in a two part Omnibus; it would be pretty damn hard to not throw that up as pretty damn epic.  Although a single omnibus (which I think you're doing) would accomplish the same thing.  However I like the format that you have, the five books have been great, only thing they're lacking is a map and an appendix at the back.

Back to the topic at hand though; I recently read R.A. Salvatore's Sellswords series and really really enjoyed them.  I then moved to the first of the Hunter's Blades trilogy and was a little disappointed.  But that could be because I lack a lot of history with those characters; any suggestions?  Does it get better?

Hunter's Blade was very much a culmination of a lot of things going on in Salvatore's Drizzt series, and present some of the first major changes to his world/characters in like, ten books or so. If you hadn't read anything prior, it definitely wouldn't have the same affect.

As for epic length...just have no desire for it. I very much pride myself on having no padding, no filler, no sidetracking the plot into wild tandems. The  Half-Orc series is longer than the Lord of the Rings...and that's my own personal definition of epic.

Hooowever, with this new sequel series to Shadowdance, I'll have the closest attempt yet to something like that, so just maybe it'll scratch that itch. And if you consider all six together as one long story spanning Haern's life over twelve years, well...I think that'll count. 

Oh, and I've got maps being made for the entire world now, so..there!

Speaking of gemmell, whold Legend is a great book, how can one not mention White Wolf?  There is a similarity between Skillgannon's search for redemption along with Harruq s.  Although it would have been interesting to put Harruq against Skillgannon
I actually haven't read that one, but now I'm curious.

Wow.  You are in for a great read.   Skillgannons actions holds as much grief and sorrow for him as it does the half orcs.  fortunately for him he has the camaraderie and guidance from Druss.  The half orcs have a more difficult ordeal.  And with the utmost respect I have found your writing and style very similar to	gemmells.  Great character development and will develop a character and have them die an unfortunate death.As a reader, it just shows how involved with the reading I.am when the passing of a character creates an emotional response.  It has made for a wonderful book (s).  Some that I find difficult to put down.  You are killing my bed time I am always asking what next and just have to read the next chapter.  

As I side note I have been thinking the elder Druss	would have made a wonderful addition to the Eschaton mercenaries as he would given Tarlac as good as he got.  But that its just fun thinking..
Having a character of mine meet one created by David Gemmell? Beyond awesome. And I think I'll grab White Wolf for my Kindle, see if I can hunt down some similarities.
Let me know what you think.  Would love to hear your thoughts.

Oh, and here's a random question, David. Will Harruq and Qurrah's mother ever make an appearance in any of your books? I'm not even sure why I want to know, but I do.
rofl
i wouldn't mind a origin story for them. Actually I would love it.

Ryne, I doubt it. I know her full story, but there isn't too much to it. For what it is worth, an orcish woman from Darnela's tribe (elf chick converting orcs back to Celestia in an attempt to cure them from their curse) fled the wedge, managing to slip past the Citadel's patrols and travel east. Because she was faithful to Celestia, more so than most, she had a fairly elvish appearance (at least compared to standard pale, ugly orcs). After suffering repeated cruel acts and hatred, she wound her way to Woodhaven, both for its reputed sympathy to other races, and as a desire to be closer to elves, whom she felt she had a closer affinity to than any other race.

WoB tells pretty clearly what happens after that (she still was an outcast, hardly knew anything of elvish society, and was a constant reminder of their race's failure centuries before), and when she's cast out, she flees, pregnant, to Veldaren. From there, she does her best to raise Harruq and Qurrah, but eventually goes to sell them to Qurrah's nameless Master because she's sick and dying. Harruq was to go too, but he fled, being the stubborn-headed fool that he is. Neither saw her again. Poor woman died homeless, alone, and never knowing what her sons would accomplish...though whether or not it'd make her happy or sad is a bit of a debate, given all the crap that goes on in the Half-Orcs.

I have some really, really old false starts to the Half-Orcs where I actually started the two brothers as children, and the first scene in the entire book is Harruq fleeing his mother as Qurrah is bought by the necromancer.

If the Half-Orc series was to be made into a series/movie/etc.  Who would play what part?  And since there is quite an abundance of memorable characters in this series; let's narrow it down to the following roles:

Who would play:  Harruq, Qurrah, Hearn, Tess, Aurelia, Brug, Delysia, and Tarlak. (Bonus: Velixar)  I'm going to need to some time to think of it as well, so, I'll post mine as soon as I have an idea.   Have fun.

message:
Okay guys, here's the deal with Dance of Death, and the Shadowdance Trilogy as a whole. I've been invited early to a new program Amazon is launching. It's a bit of an experiment, but I'm going to see how well it plays out. Part of it, however, is this condition: six months exclusivity to Amazon.com

That means, Dance of Death is not coming to the iBookstore for at least six months.

Okay, now before you kill me, there are still a couple ways to get it fairly easily. One, just download the Kindle app. If you want to have it actually in your iBook catalog, you can also buy the epub version here: http://www.smashwords.com/books/view/103165 from Smashwords, and it'll integrate no problem.

If you absolutely, positively cannot get it either way, let me know through an email. I'll hook you up, I promise. Sorry for any frustration. This kinda came out of nowhere just last week.

data.message: Thanks for the high compliments, Nikholas. Glad I could entertain even having to follow after The Hunger Games. I mean, you couldn't, I don't know, read some bad fanfiction beforehand to make me seem even more awesome? ;-)

I enjoyed The Hunger Games, but they are not really my cup of tea. Some of my favorites are The Mistborn series by Brandon Sanderson and Joe Abercrombie's "The first Law". And of course, "the Wheel of Time" And, while I would not have put "the weight of blood" on that level of writing, the characters, story, and world you are creating is getting better with every word you write, and with this world you have an opportunity to create a lasting and immersing fantasy that will have your name mentioned right along with them.
I wouldn't put Weight of Blood in the same *library* as Wheel of Time, either, but I'll keep doing the best I can to entertain!

message:
So, with the year ending, I figured I'd go ahead and announce my goals to have completed by next year. May not hit it, but I should get close, especially with The Old Ways hitting very close to December.

Paladins #3: The Old Ways.
Sequel Trilogy to Shadowdance: Book 1
Paladins #4
Sequel Trilogy to Shadowdance: Book 2
Sequel Series to Half-Orcs: Book 1
Sequel Trilogy to Shadowdance: Book 3

That's right, guys. I've begun plotting more insanity with Haern, and it is big. Epic. We're talking a giant web of conspiracies, unlike the three standalones for Shadowdance, and everyone is involved. *Everyone*. Thren, Antonil, Deathmask, the elves, the Trifect, the thieves, the Eschaton, plus a nice selection of brand new people to lie, cheat, and kill. I haven't been this excited plotting out a story in a very, very long time.

data.message: Shared with my husband, Jeffrey, who can certainly relate! (Dawn: *rolled 1 on skill check* Jeffrey: "Your huge holy symbol looks like a 3-legged bearded cow. Andi: "We can use it as a sign for our shop!" Richard: "We'll call the shop the Divine Bovine!") That cow will haunt him for the rest of his days. <insert evil laugh here>
So much of D&D is inside jokes and nerdy humor, but I thought this story had a pretty universal appeal in how bad the campaign went to crap.
Thank you for the stumble down memory lane! I love it when the opportunity presents itself to share your stuff with friends and family. :)
I'm glad you stuck with your own creative inspirations! Friends usually have bad ideas, at least mine do...

data.message: Kym, I'm in charge of the price of all my books, so don't worry about cost or anything like that. I'm making a very fine living doing what I love.
Oh, and you can read any of the various series in any order you want.  They all intertwine. In terms of chronologically, it'd be Shadowdance - Paladins - Half-Orcs.
Ok, so I started in the middle and am moving clockwise. Lovely, thanks. Very glad it works out financially for you, cos it's certainly working out financially for me. Lol

I wrote Paladins as a purposeful new place for readers to try out some of my work, so you got a solid opening there. Long as you're enjoying the Half-Orcs, you'll be fine. The Shadowdance series is very much standalone, and a little different from the rest. You won't be hurting having not read it, and if you do go check it out after finishing Half-Orcs, you'll see all the tiny little references I sneaked in.

Looking forward to it! Have just been getting my introduction to the curly eared brothers with the mirror image names and dubious morals and am eager to see what kind of necromantic hi jinx they get up to. :)
Oh well, just stuff like blowing up villages, instigating demonic invasions, marrying half-mad goddess...you know. The usual.
Perfect! That's me set for the next few weeks then. Fluffy slippers, packet of choc chip bickies, and some good old fashioned exploding demonic mad goddess'! Bliss!

data.message: Your books remind me of a couple of fantastic (okay, I'll say it...EPIC) RP games my husband created and ran for me and a few close friends years ago (this is high praise indeed). I swear, the quips thrown between characters in your dialog were deja vu moments from the past coming back to haunt me. Your characters were so multi-dimensional that there were moments I even liked your villains...if only for a moment. As my husband always says...you can't have heroic heroes without truly vile villains! And every vile villain must always have moments of humanity just as every hero must struggle with the darkness within. Thank you for your memorable characters!

Andrea, you're more than welcome for the entertainment. I'm just flattered by everything you have to say. And yeah, I think pretty much anyone who has played a D&D game will have that immediately feeling of familiarity with the bickering, especially between the members of the Eschaton.

And I love my villains. Love them. Without a good villain, I get bored, so I probably give them more screen time than they even deserve ;-)

(Doh, just noticed the following comments...bad Facebook, tell me when there's new posts!)

Anyway...wow. I almost feel like you're describing a different author. Consider me that flattered. I wanted to tell a lengthy story, all about the fall and redemption of one brother, and the love of the other that manages to deny the deserved anger and hatred. I don't think I succeeded every time, but by the final novel, I think everyone who's been reading could enjoy the utter joy I had in all that madness :-)

Awesome to hear, Ryne. And just wait until you hit book 4. There's a pretty marked step up in quality ;-)

And I like Tessanna too. She's always, always fun to write.

That should be interesting to see then.

I still find it funny how dark your writing is when you're such a nice guy. Of course, it might be just as funny that some of the darkest bits are my favorite.
It's always the nice guys you don't suspect...

Haha, I know what you mean.

When exactly did you realize that your writing had a dark slant to it? I remember the author's note at the back of The Weight of Blood where you said you didn't realize exactly how dark it was until you had a few reviews, but I assume you knew it had a dark slant to it nonetheless.
I realized how dark it was when I started getting review after review saying as much. Guess it was just leftover remnants of a D&D gamer mentality, where high bodycounts just part of the exp grab ;-)
I didn't think the high bodycounts made it that dark. ;-)
Some of the things the characters do, on the other hand, is pretty dark. Still, I like how dirty your characters fight.

Just saw your review for CoB. Yeah, it's definitely a darker story. Something you might want to realize: Qurrah's the villain for the middle of the series. Seriously. Sympathetic, maybe, but I really, really wanted people to want him dead by the end of book 2.

Yeah, I'm reviewing every indie book I read, so you can expect one review from me for every book you have out. Well, I doubt I'll read Land of Ash, but all the others, definitely.

And I suspected that Qurrah had such a role. My biggest problem with him was because I couldn't sympathize with him, but I found it hard to hate him too. His motivations were clear and strong. If I put myself in his shoes, I could completely understand the actions, and that scared me.
Just so you know, I just left a review on Book 3.

On another note, you've taken the place as my favorite author, and it's not just because you're a great guy that doesn't mind interacting with fans. ;-)

data.message:
I do get this question asked a lot.

For earlier works, like the Half-Orcs, it is very much in the same style as R. A. Salvatore and his Drizzt Series (a good starting point is Homeland, the first book of the Dark Elf Trilogy).

For The Shadowdance Trilogy, it'd be a combination of two authors. The first is Brent Weeks and his Night Angel Trilogy (it's not a fluke the covers share certain similar elements). The second is G. R. R. Martin's A Game of Thrones. A lot of the politics, families, and betrayal all came from a desire to match his amazing worldbuilding.

The newest series I'm about to put out (I swear I'll make an announcement soon) is very much akin to David Gemmell's earlier works, such as Legend, or the Rigante Series. Discovered Gemmell pretty recently, but he's a writer after my own heart, and the Paladins is a purposeful attempt to incorporate some of his style into my own.

I hope any of this helps :-)
thanks a lot for that David, Ill make sure to give some of those a read, bloody knew there was some nightangel inspiration in shadowdance lol

Yeah, I was about...three chapters into writing Dance of Cloaks when I started reading Way of Shadows. Was like...ah what the heck? This guy's making me look like an amateur...or a bigger amateur...something like that.

People kept saying I was like David Gemmell, and I would always shrug and wonder "Um, okay, never read 'em." Finally did, and my reaction was this:

"Ooooooohhh, I get it. I -wish- I was like David Gemmell."

Well he passed away so you can take all
His fans. :)

***SPOILER***  Cant say I agree there, I found parts of that hard to follow, the way you weren't sure if something was crucial point or not untill you read on. I think the best scene had to be, well technically more than one scene, Leo Connington's mansion, I love how you can track the progress of Ghost and Haern/Senke, the suspense it creates, and how their meeting utterly shattered any preconcieved notions of how you thought it would play out, and the fight scene itself was imaginative and easy to follow, so you could really visual the exchange of blows, brought to an emotional climax as Haern explains what happened to Tarlak, truly a great scene. Hope I didn't give too much away there, I tried to be spoiler concious, added a spoiler alert just incase, don't want to ruin your wonderful work for anyone David. Congratualtions one again, as it truly was wonderful, I only just finished reading it.

I also realise that is a rather obvious choice, being the relative ending (not the final scene but definetly the climax of the book, but I feel it really did surpase all others, it was well planned out, easy to follow, suspenseful, exciting and emotional, what more could you want from a scene!

data.message: I did, actually, but someone mentioned this idea to me an email as well, and brought up a point that hit home. He didn't want the focus removed from the characters, particularly Harruq, and instead placed on the other gods. I agreed, and realized I was in danger of doing just that. It's one thing for Harruq to succeed in defeating Thulos with Ashhur's aid. It's another entirely for him to simply be there while Ashhur gets the win.

I understand i figured that i just wanted to see wat you said... You did an amazing job..i remember months ago seeing the first book and just being bored downloaded it and im glad i did...im bout to download your other books and you have to keep facebook update with wat you wrote at the end of book five..idc if u charge 20 dollars for it i would buy it

What did I write at the end of book 5...oh, about the angels, Ker and Mordan, Aurelia's, um, predicament...yeah. Once I finish Dance of Blades, I'll need to decide what I write next: another Harruq and Qurrah novel, or a standalone for the paladins.
Paladins!!! I love the halforcs but paladins would be epic.
I got a soft spot for 'em too. If I write Fall of the Citadel, it'd allow me to also hang around with Velixar again. All kinds of fun there.
I want back story on the paladins especially Jericho. That shield was badass.

Problem with that is figuring out how to sneak him in. Blatantly say he wasn't there when the Citadel fell when introducing him in Death of Promises. The Citadel's destruction was the main focus of, well, The Fall of the Citadel (book title). May just have to spend a week giving Jerico his own little novella.
that's even better!!!! Or have him out doing side story that ties into the fall of the citadel. Holding back an army that is trying to get to the Citadel.
did u ever have anything thought up or drawn up of wat ashhur or karak would have looked like in person themselves

Actually, I've described Karak before. Basically the statue of him in the priests of Karak's temple in Veldaren details pretty clearly how I thought he'd look. As for Ashhur, I can't entirely remember, though I think I gave a brief description of him on the painting behind the throne in Veldaren, after they yank downt eh curtain.

p.s. Not sure what authors have to do, but for future reference it would be nice if your books had a proper linked TOC and chapter tags for Kindle books.  The chapter tagging would show ticks in the progress bar for each chapter location and you can go from chapter to chapter with the navigation buttons.  The new page number support needs special tagging as well apparently.
I noticed that new page number thing yesterday. I need to look more into that.

david it's not really all that amazing. the only way to see it is to hit the menu button. Basically the new update only shows the % done. if you press menu it shows page count if it's available and the old system. If I was reading one of your books why would I hit menu to know where I am at?

I just think it's nice for readers to have some sort of way to compare books in terms of length. People understand what it means to have a 300 page book. But what does it mean to have a book 15,000 locations long?
I thought the same thing when I first got my kindle. Then like 5 books in I actually got used to the locations.

"Forty percent, eh? Have you gotten to the lengthy bridge battle with Qurrah? Probably my favorite part in the whole book."

data.message:
I am an education major at the University of Dayton, and hence spend a lot of time with the City of Dayton's very poor youth.  I can tell you some of the horror stories of these young men and women, and it is heart breaking.  Your characters motivations were real, and they showed the actions of those who had been abused and hungry for all of their lives.  Do not be sorry for writing a book that contained characters that went outside the norm.  You captured real emotions with those fictional half-orcs.  As an aspiring writer myself, I look up to authors like you who are capable of spinning tales without relying on cliche characters.  I look forward to finishing the series!

Best Regards from your new biggest fan,

Fletcher
Awesome! Great job!

data.message: Dance of Cloaks was an excellent read, and I highly recommend it!!
Thanks Julie :-)

I loved dance of cloaks, it was fantasy that you could immerse yourself in and relate to so completely, for everything the characters went through, they were just human, no magic, no special abilities, just real people whose only talents were their dedication and training. superb to read, total escapism, and everything fantasy should be, without the fantasy.

It's going to be tough trying to top it, but I've got some plans for its sequel. The key will be to keep things low-key still, because I plan on bringing Tarlak into the mix, and if there is anything he isn't, it's low-key.

And thanks, Josh. I can't imagine a higher compliment than all that.

i don't know, i think Tarlak can be deceptively low key, because when he's around you just can't miss him between the bright yellow robes and boisterous nature , it's what he's doing behind the scenes, always up to something, always thinking things through, and seems to spend a lot of time preparing for things unbeknown to anyone
and by the way David, I'm really glad to hear your bringing Dance of cloaks in to its potential as a prequel series instead of just a stand alone book, cheers for the hint :)

Yeah, plus Tarlak should be still learning a lot of his magic, so when he does cast, I can keep it small. Just need to keep things under control is all, and I've got a few ideas about how to do that.

Oh, and you can't take -all- the credit for a prequel series. Originally where Dance of Cloaks ended was only halfway through my intended storyline, but going all the way to the end would have resulted in some massive 700 page tome. Gotta finish up my original plan!

That, and the stupid amount of sales its getting is certainly making the idea of a sequel exciting :-)

what's wrong with 700 page tomes? lol
if you can write a book that will last me a week I'll kiss your feet David
it was great, can't wait for the sequel

data.message: I stumbled across 'The Weight Of Blood' only 2 weeks ago, and have just completed 'The Shadows of Grace' and I have no idea how I will bear the wait for 'A Sliver of Redemption'. The story itself is wonderful, a thrilling tale of redemption, condemnation, hope and despair, Set in a world so magical and in-depth it leaves you reeling for another glimpse into the land of Dezrel, and no doubt looking into the other books set in it. The writing style takes this already enchanting story, and makes it a pleasure to read, the imagery is powerful, and the metaphors precise, and on several occasions I could not contain my laughter at the sarcastic quip or a quick witted comment of one of Daglish's truly superbly crafted characters. I cannot wait for the final instalment, and strongly suspect once this masterpiece is complete, The Half Orc series, may come to rival even The Malloreon, or the Discworld novels.
It has truly been a pleasure to read so far, and I look forward to continuing my journey with the Eschaton, The brothers Tun, and David Dalglish.

Why thank you David, although i forgot to mention i noticed none of this untill i finished reading the books, because at the time i was too busy enjoying them, and i started dance of cloaks this morning :)
and I love the irony of the author praising something i wrote lol
Haha, I'm just glad you found your way over here. And trust me, reading a review like that is just an incredible thrill.

dance of cloaks is truly remarkable, im finding the suspense and longing to find out more of Haern's beginnings unbearable, and it raises some interesting questions, i wonder if you would do an online Q&A for fans, possibly set up a formspring page would be a simple way to do it, thanks for the kind comments David, i never thought writing a review would lead to a chance to speak to the author

one other thing, why does everyone get stabbed in the eye? surely the temple would be most murders choice after the throat, due to its effectiveness and minimal mess. A part of me suspects although you never intended to write a dark fantasy, your having a lot of fun with all this gore.

If I'm not having fun writing this series, man, what's the point? Though I must say I'm not noticed myself killing too many through the eye. I'll have to start paying attention now. Would hate to become predictable :-)

As for Q&A, I've done a couple on various reviews (they should all be linked here from this page) and of course I'll respond to anything posted here or emailed to me.
in that case, was Haern's true name to be revealed in the final book, or did you not intend to reveal it (or even for Haern to be his true name) until you started writing a dance of cloaks?

Basically Aaron abandons the name and goes by Haern for a good7-8 years in the time between Dance and Cost of Betrayal. To him, that is his true name. Wrote Cost before I knew a lot of this, otherwise I'd obviously have hinted at far more in Thren and Haern's final confrontation.
i thought so :) and I love how you just said "before I knew" not "before I thought of"  it lets me know I'm not the only one who gets so carried away I forget its not real lol
Huh. You're right.

Don't worry, there is no charge for participating in PubIt! Your credit card will only be charged in the unlikely event that you receive more returns than sales in a given payment cycle and therefore have a negative balance.

data.message: The characters are still well-drawn and engaging, but here there is even more conflict between the two brothers Harruq and Qurrah, along with more action and emotional engagement. The many action sequences are masterfully handled, and pull no punches. The characters are fully fleshed out (and in some cases de-fleshed) and believable. If you enjoyed The Weight of Blood, definitely continue on with this series. I would gladly have paid the full price of a hardcover if I had known how good this would be."

message: So for about three days, my Omnibus was the featured book on the iBookstore Science Fiction and Fantasy section. Friggin' awesome.
Our wizard leader is upset. I offered to help him, but he looked scared at the idea. It made Qurrah jealous, so I don’t mind the rejection.
So much effort to be so hated...and all for an accident. All for Harruq's weakness. I will not take the blame. Not here. Now now.

Ok, I finished the Cost of Betrayal last night and had to give it some time before posting about it.  First I loved the book and it was an excellent story.  However, I hated the ending, or what happened at the ending I should say.  Talk about being pissed!  I assumed that before I started CoB, that I would hate Qurrah, well I was wrong.  I do not hate him, I FRIGGIN HATE him!  The arrogant, stuck-up, Half-Orc Bastard!  Oh and please do not get me started on Velixar!  Don’t get me wrong, I Love the books, but not the ending I was looking for.  Oh and yes, I already bought The Death of Promises and starting it now!  I had so many other to-be-read books to read, but they will have to wait because I’m hooked on these!
Note to self: when you need heads smashed quietly, do not send the half-orc. Or Brug. And not both at the same time, you stupid, idiot mercenary captain.

I wrote up a little short story detailing a cross-over between Harruq Tun and Tessanna Delone fighting a half-demon named Laila from the novel Flaming Dove. Anyone interested in a silly little read, feel free to check it out.
My brother seems so smitten over that elf. She seems to love him back. I wonder if that will be enough for him. Would it last, if Velixar returned?
Can’t figure out why, but I’d swear my armor keeps itching against my neck ever since Brug fixed it.

data.message:
Thren Felhorn would stop at nothing to bend his son to his will and make him into a heartless assassin and the next ruler of the thieves guilds. Sub-plots involved a variety of other characters vying for money or power. There are also two very different religions struggling to win the people to their respective beliefs. 

The action scenes--and there are many--are so well-written that I could easily imagine myself observing as if from a nearby vantage point. But not too nearby--the vivid battle and torture descriptions are not for the squeamish.

The main characters are portrayed with depth and feeling and each is given a story that we follow throughout the book. I especially liked that the women were strong characters and some of them could fight as well as or better than the men. 

All the action and conflict lead to a climactic event when Thren Felhorn, ruler of the thieves, attempts to wipe out the opposition and finally take control of everything. Some of the characters live and some die violently, but loose ends are tied up in a dramatic battle that overtakes the city. 

Highly recommended.
